questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a well-child examination. She feels well. She is performing well in school and getting good grades. She is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lbs); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg in the left arm and 110/74 mm Hg in the left leg. Physical examination shows an unusually short and broad neck with bilateral excess skin folds that extend to the shoulders and low-set ears. There is an increased carrying angle when she fully extends her arms at her sides. An x-ray of the chest shows inferior rib notching. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Horseshoe adrenal gland on abdominal CT
Triphalangeal thumb on upper extremity x-ray
Mutation of FBN1 on genetic testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A horseshoe adrenal gland is a very rare anomaly. It can be seen as an isolated abnormality or in association with a genetic syndrome, such as Ivemark syndrome. A horseshoe kidney, not a horseshoe adrenal gland, is an anomaly seen in approx. 10% of patients with Turner syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolonged aPTT is characteristic of Noonan syndrome. This condition was formerly thought to be a subset of Turner syndrome due to very similar clinical features, notably short stature and a webbed neck. However, the cardiovascular malformations are different. Noonan syndrome classically causes pulmonary stenosis, which would not produce the rib notching seen in this patient's x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

Triphalangeal thumb can be seen as an isolated abnormality or in association with a genetic syndrome, such as Diamond-Blackfan anemia. This patient has some features that are consistent with this condition, such as low set ears and short stature, but it would not explain the differential in blood pressure between the upper and lower extremities or the rib notching seen on x-ray.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is associated with several genetic conditions, such as Marfan syndrome or Klinefelter syndrome, but does not have a significant association with Turner syndrome. Patients with Klinefelter syndrome are phenotypical male, which rules this condition out. Patients with both Klinefelter syndrome or Marfan syndrome tend to develop a tall, slim stature and long extremities. Neither condition is associated with short stature, CoA, webbed neck (excess skin folds), or cubitus valgus.

E) INCORRECT:

Uterine agenesis is consistent with Müllerian agenesis, which is not a genitourinary feature of Turner syndrome and typically develops in individuals with a 46,XX karyotype. The condition is typically diagnosed during a gynecologic examination, at which point the absence of some or all of the vagina, cervix, and uterus is seen on the examination.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutation of FBN1 (also known as fibrillin-1) is responsible for Marfan syndrome. This patient's short stature makes Marfan syndrome unlikely, as patients with this condition are typically tall and slim with long fingers. Cardiovascular involvement can include mitral valve prolapse or aortic aneurysm, neither of which are seen in this patient.

G) CORRECT:

Gonadal dysgenesis and subsequent streak ovaries are characteristic findings in Turner syndrome. Failure of the germ cells to develop into ovaries results in deposition of hormonally inactive connective tissue. The absence of functional ovaries leads to deficiency of estrogen and progesterone, which causes delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, infertility, and osteoporosis.
questions.hint: This patient's findings of inferior rib notching and difference in systolic blood pressure ≥ 20 mm Hg between the left arm and leg are consistent with coarctation of the aorta (CoA). CoA, short stature, webbed neck (excess skin folds), and cubitus valgus (increased carrying angle) deformity are characteristic features of Turner syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not yet had her first menstrual period. She reports that she frequently experiences cramping and pain in her legs during school sports. The patient is at the 20th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a high-arched palate with maloccluded teeth and a low posterior hairline. The patient has a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Pelvic examination shows normal external female genitalia. There is scant pubic hair. Without appropriate treatment, this patient is at the greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Obsessive-compulsive disorder is associated with eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa, which is more common in female individuals and can manifest with primary amenorrhea due to chronic undernutrition. However, this patient is neither underweight nor is there a history of eating disorders.

B) CORRECT:

Ovarian dysgenesis is one of the most common features of Turner syndrome. Since the ovaries are the predominant source of estrogen, many patients with Turner syndrome have estrogen deficiency, resulting in increased osteoclast activity, decreased osteoblast activity, and bone reabsorption. This places these patients at increased risk for osteoporosis and pathologic fractures. Therefore, almost all patients with Turner syndrome require estrogen and progesterone replacement therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is one of the classic cardiac defects seen in patients with Noonan syndrome. Although Noonan syndrome is clinically similar to Turner syndrome (e.g., short stature, high arched palate, webbed neck, chest deformity), this patient presents with primary amenorrhea and signs of aortic coarctation, which are inconsistent with Noonan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe acne is commonly seen in patients with double Y syndrome. Unlike patients with Turner syndrome, individuals with double Y syndrome have a male phenotype, mildly delayed motor and language development, and, typically, tall stature due to excess growth hormone.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperphagia is associated with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS). Although PWS can also manifest with short stature and gonadal dysfunction (resulting in delayed menarche), this patient lacks other features of PWS, such as intellectual disability, progressive obesity, abnormal facial features (e.g., almond-shaped eyes), and history of hypotonia and feeding difficulty during infancy.

F) INCORRECT:

Upward lens dislocation is associated with Marfan syndrome and is caused by defects in the ciliary zonules. Although patients with Marfan syndrome also often have a high-arched palate and cardiac abnormalities, they typically have aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, and/or ascending aortic aneurysm rather than aortic coarctation. Furthermore, Marfan syndrome is associated with tall stature, long extremities, arachnodactyly, pectus deformity, and joint hypermobility, none of which is seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Acute myeloid leukemia and acute lymphoblastic leukemia are commonly associated with Down syndrome. Although patients with Down syndrome also have short stature and physical anomalies, this patient lacks the classic features of Down syndrome, including intellectual disability and facial anomalies (e.g., upward slanting palpebral fissures, epicanthus). Amenorrhea, delayed puberty, low hairline, and a broad chest are not features of Down syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient presents with short stature, primary amenorrhea, delayed puberty, a high-arched palate, maloccluded teeth, low hairline, broad chest, and signs of aortic coarctation (hypertension, lower extremity claudication), all of which are consistent with Turner syndrome.

questions.text: A 3400-g (7-lb 8-oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of bilateral upper and lower extremities and low-set ears. The posterior hairline is low and the chest appears broad. There are skin folds running down the sides of the neck to the shoulders. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur and systolic click are heard at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's swelling?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal retention of sodium can be a compensatory response to decreased kidney perfusion (resulting from, e.g., heart failure or chronic kidney disease) and can cause edema of the extremities. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which is associated with both cardiovascular abnormalities (e.g., bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension) and kidney disease (e.g., horseshoe kidneys) that can progress to severe cardiac or renal insufficiency with consequent renal hypoperfusion. However, this child has no other signs and symptoms to suggest cardiac or renal insufficiency. In addition, edema of the hands and feet in neonates with Turner syndrome has a different underlying mechanism.

B) CORRECT:

Dysfunction of the lymphatic system is characteristic of Turner syndrome and typically leads to congenital lymphedema of the hands and feet starting in the neonatal period. The precise cause of lymphatic dysfunction in Turner syndrome is unknown. This patient also has other typical features of the condition, such as a female phenotype, shield chest, a short, webbed neck, low-set ears, and signs of a bicuspid aortic valve (grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur and systolic click at the apex).

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired protein synthesis (e.g., in liver disease) can lead to decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and subsequent accumulation of fluid in the extracellular space. However, fluid primarily builds up in the peritoneal cavity in the form of ascites, rather than in the hands and feet. Additionally, this newborn has no other signs of liver disease, such as jaundice. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Excessive urinary protein loss (e.g., in nephrotic syndrome) can lead to decreased serum colloid osmotic pressure and subsequent edema. However, nephrotic syndrome is rare in newborns and the edema in nephrotic syndrome typically begins in the periorbital region rather than the extremities. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired left ventricular (LV) function can cause increased hydrostatic pressure and subsequent edema via two main mechanisms: increased renal sodium retention (as a response to decreased renal perfusion) and increased venous pressure. This newborn has a systolic murmur that suggests a bicuspid aortic valve, which could progress to aortic stenosis or insufficiency and cause left-sided heart failure (LHF). However, LHF typically manifests with signs of pulmonary (e.g., tachypnea, basilar rales) rather than peripheral edema. Furthermore, this patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased capillary permeability (e.g., due to inflammation, burns, allergic reactions) can lead to extravasation of fluid into the tissue and subsequent edema. However, edema is usually localized to the area of tissue injury or generalized in systemic reactions (e.g., sepsis, anaphylaxis). Peripheral edema of the hands and feet bilaterally would be untypical. Furthermore, this patient shows no symptoms of localized tissue damage such as erythema, and her normal vital signs make a systemic reaction unlikely. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.
questions.hint: This newborn's systolic ejection murmur and systolic click at the apex suggest a functional bicuspid aortic valve.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not yet attained menarche. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (139 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Examination shows normal breast development. Scant axillary hair is present. Abdominal examination shows a firm, nontender left inguinal mass. Pelvic examination shows a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography does not show a uterus or ovaries. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in the SRY gene on chromosome Y results in Swyer syndrome, which manifests with primary amenorrhea and absent or atretic ovaries on ultrasound. However, normal development of axillary hair would occur (due to adrenal androgens), and a uterus would be present. Also, breast development would be impaired, and palpable testes would not be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Mullerian duct agenesis results in primary amenorrhea, an absent uterus on ultrasound, and a blind vaginal pouch due to vaginal atresia. However, the ovaries would be present. Axillary hair growth would also be normal since primary amenorrhea in patients with Mullerian duct agenesis is the result of an anatomical defect and not a hormonal one.

C) INCORRECT:

Five-alpha-reductase deficiency can manifest with primary amenorrhea, female external genitalia with an inguinal testis, and the absence of ovaries and the uterus on ultrasound. However, breast development does not usually occur, and patients would typically have some degree of virilization (e.g., hirsutism, clitoromegaly) at the time of puberty.
Image Description:

Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.

D) INCORRECT:

A form of sex chromosomal mosaicism called mixed gonadal dysgenesis (characterized by a 45, XO/XY karyotype) may result in a single inguinal testis, with features of Turner syndrome such as primary amenorrhea and absent or atretic ovaries on ultrasound. Breast development, however, would also be impaired, and a unicornuate uterus or a fallopian tube remnant would be seen on ultrasound on the side without the testicle. Other features would also be seen, such as neck webbing, a low hairline, short stature, shield chest, lymphedema, intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and/or renal anomalies.

E) INCORRECT:

Sex chromosomal monosomy is the underlying pathophysiology of Turner syndrome, which can manifest with primary amenorrhea, normal external genitalia with a patent introitus, and atretic or absent ovaries on ultrasound. However, breast development would be impaired, an inguinal testicle and vaginal atresia would not be expected, and the uterus would be seen on ultrasound. Other features would also be seen, such as neck webbing, a low hairline, short stature, a cubitus valgus defect, shield chest, lymphedema, intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and/or renal anomalies.

F) CORRECT:

Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) are karyotypically male (XY). The Y chromosome results in the formation of the testes (instead of the ovaries) from the undifferentiated fetal gonad. The uterus does not develop because the anti-Mullerian hormone secreted by the testes causes Mullerian duct atresia. However, the genital tubercle in AIS is not responsive to testosterone, so masculinization of the external genitalia does not occur. AIS also results in a failure of the cranial suspensory ligament to regress, meaning the testes remain in the inguinal canal or abdomen instead of the perineal region. Patients are born with female external genitalia and are generally raised as women. At the time of puberty, axillary and pubic hair growth is also absent or decreased since cutaneous androgen receptors lack sensitivity. Breast development occurs despite the absence of ovaries since aromatase in adipose tissue converts androgens produced by the inguinal testes to estradiol.

Hormonal analysis in patients with AIS shows elevated LH levels due to insensitivity of the pituitary gland to androgen and possibly elevated testosterone levels due to stimulation of the Leydig cells by LH. The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing, which shows a mutation in the AR gene on chromosome Xq. Patients with complete AIS usually have a female gender identity.
questions.hint: This patient's serum luteinizing hormone (LH) and testosterone levels will both be elevated.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 57 kg (125 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the breasts shows a secondary mound formed by the nipple and areola. Pubic hair is sparse and lightly pigmented. Abdominal examination shows bilateral firm, nontender inguinal masses. Pelvic examination shows a blind-ended vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography does not show a uterus or ovaries. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone therapy is used in the treatment of 17α-hydroxylase deficiency to counteract high levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone (an aldosterone precursor). Although 17α-hydroxylase deficiency is characterized by a lack of secondary sexual characteristics (e.g., scant pubic hair, primary amenorrhea, underdeveloped breast), most patients develop hypertension in childhood and electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hypernatremia, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis), none of which are seen here.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS). Patients with AIS are phenotypically female with a male karyotype (XY); the presence of a Y chromosome results in the formation of the testes instead of the ovaries, which secrete testosterone. However, as patients with AIS have a defective androgen receptor, there is no response to testosterone and, therefore, patients lack male external genitalia and male secondary sexual characteristics. In addition, testosterone can be peripherally converted into estrogen, which promotes female breast and pubertal development.

AIS also prevents the cranial suspensory ligament from regressing and therefore the testes remain in the inguinal canal or abdomen. Because of the increased risk of malignant transformation of the cryptorchid testes, patients with AIS require an orchiectomy. Most patients delay surgery until after puberty to allow for full pubertal development and attainment of adult height. After surgery, patients who identify as women require estrogen replacement therapy. In patients with partial AIS, orchiectomy is usually performed before puberty and hormone replacement therapy (based on the individual's gender identity) may be initiated at the beginning of expected puberty. Throughout this process, patients and their families should receive appropriate psychological support to ensure that treatment (particularly any hormone replacement therapy) is in line with the patient's wishes and gender identity.

C) INCORRECT:

Testosterone therapy can be used to treat male individuals with hypogonadism. The efficacy of high-dose androgen therapy in resolving androgen resistance in individuals with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) who identify as men has not been proven. In individuals with AIS who identify as women, testosterone therapy would not be used, as testosterone levels are already abnormally high from loss of negative feedback from the defective androgen receptor. It would be inappropriate to initiate testosterone therapy in this patient before the gender identity has been confirmed without a doubt.

D) INCORRECT:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome manifests with a blind-ended vaginal pouch (as seen in this patient) and uterine agenesis, which results in infertility as well as primary amenorrhea. During fetal development, the Sertoli cells in the undescended testes continue to secrete Mullerian inhibitory factor, which causes the obliteration of the Mullerian duct and, consequently, the absence of structures that derive from it (i.e., fallopian tubes, uterus, uterine cervix, and proximal third of the vagina). Because the vagina is rudimentary, some patients undergo dilatory therapy to allow for sexual activity. However, this treatment is based on patient preference and is not a medical requirement.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid replacement therapy, (e.g., prednisolone), is the treatment of choice for all forms of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), in which various enzyme defects prevent the normal synthesis of cortisol. In the most common form of CAH, female patients present with virilization and salt wasting in infancy, not the lack of secondary sexual development seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's serum luteinizing hormone and testosterone levels will be abnormal.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she has not had her menstrual period yet. At birth, she was found to have partial labial fusion and clitoromegaly. Her mother reports that during pregnancy she had noticed abnormal hair growth on her chin. The girl has severe acne. Three years ago, she broke her wrist after minor trauma. Last year, she sustained a spinal compression fracture after lifting a box during a move. She currently takes oral isotretinoin and an oral contraceptive. The patient is at the 97th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows numerous inflamed pustules on her face and upper back. Breast development is at Tanner stage I. The patient refuses to have a pelvic examination. Pelvic ultrasound shows multiple ovarian cysts and a normal uterus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) can manifest with amenorrhea and symptoms of hyperandrogenism, such as severe acne or hirsutism. While the ultrasound finding of multiple ovarian cysts raises suspicion for this diagnosis, PCOS would not explain the presence of ambiguous genitalia at birth, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, tall stature, or osteoporosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a common cause of female pseudohermaphroditism and may manifest with virilization and menstrual irregularities, both of which are seen here. However, affected female individuals usually have precocious puberty with the early development of female secondary sexual characteristics (due to synthesis of estrogens from excess androgens). In addition, they typically present earlier in childhood with salt-wasting and hypotension (in 21β-hydroxylase deficiency) or hypertension (in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency). Moreover, CAH does not explain this patient's tall stature or her mother's history of virilization during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Müllerian agenesis may manifest with primary amenorrhea in a phenotypically female patient with normal ovaries, as seen in this case, but a uterus and other derivatives of the Mullerian ducts would not be present. Furthermore, secondary sexual characteristics would be normal. Since both estrogen and androgen levels are normal in these patients, they typically present with unambiguous female rather than ambiguous external genitalia and virilization would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia may cause primary amenorrhea by suppressing GnRH, which results in decreased levels of luteinizing hormone as well as follicle-stimulating hormone and subsequently decreased levels of estrogen and testosterone (i.e., hypogonatrophic hypogonadism). Since androgen levels are low, virilization and ambiguous external genitalia would not be expected at birth. In addition, symptoms of the underlying cause, such as headaches and impaired vision in patients with hyperprolactinoma, are usually present. Although oral contraceptive pills are a risk factor for the development of hyperprolactinemia (estrogen stimulates prolactin production), this patient's findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

An imperforate hymen is a possible cause of primary amenorrhea. Patients with an imperforate hymen usually present at puberty with periodic abdominal pain. Secondary sexual characteristics would develop normally. In addition, a tall stature, osteoporosis, and virilization would not be expected with an imperforate hymen. These features suggest a disturbance of the sex hormones rather than just an anatomical variant.

F) INCORRECT:

Turner syndrome may manifest in patients who are phenotypically female with delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea. However, in contrast to this patient, children with Turner syndrome usually have short rather than tall stature and streak ovaries. Furthermore, osteoporosis usually occurs later in life. Moreover, a lack of additional features of Turner syndrome such as a webbed neck or widely spaced nipples, makes the diagnosis unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Amenorrhea (secondary or primary) should always raise suspicion for pregnancy, even if the patient takes oral contraceptive pills. However, this girl has no other findings consistent with pregnancy (e.g., weight gain, breast enlargement, discomfort), making the diagnosis unlikely. In addition, pregnancy would not explain the presence of ambiguous genitalia at birth, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, tall stature, or osteoporosis. While certain fetal conditions or abnormalities of the placenta may lead to virilization in the pregnant mother, gestational virilization would not explain this girl's severe acne over 2 years.

H) CORRECT:

Individuals with aromatase deficiency are unable to convert androgens to estrogens. Therefore, karyotypically female (46 XX) patients are born with ambiguous external genitalia and female internal reproductive organs. At puberty, affected individuals typically present with absent secondary sexual characteristics, amenorrhea (due to absent estrogen activity and the development of ovarian cysts, which impair ovulation), and features of virilization (due to increased testosterone levels). In addition, both men and women have a tall stature due to a delayed fusion of the epiphyseal growth plates, and signs of osteoporosis (e.g., bone fractures after minor trauma; caused by estrogen deficiency). Mothers of affected children may also have a history of developing similar features during pregnancy due to fetal androgens crossing the placenta.
questions.hint: This patient presented with ambiguous genitalia as an infant, and now during puberty, presents with primary amenorrhea, severe acne, tall stature, delayed breast development, and features of osteoporosis. These findings are consistent with low estrogen and high androgen levels. Her mother also experienced symptoms of virilization during pregnancy, which is another characteristic feature of this patient's disease.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child visit. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery and has been healthy except for occasional episodes of asthma. He attends a junior high school and is having difficulties keeping up with his classmates in many classes. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His only medication is an albuterol inhaler. His immunizations are up-to-date. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a high-frequency midsystolic click that is best heard at the left fifth intercostal space. The patient has long extremities along with excess breast tissue bilaterally. He has no axillary hair. Genital examination shows reduced scrotal size and a normal-sized penis. Which of the following tests is the most likely to diagnose the patient's underlying disorder?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased IGF-1 levels in an adolecscent with tall stature would suggest a diagnosis of excess growth hormone caused by a growth-hormone secreting pituitary adenoma (gigantism). A large pituitary adenoma can also cause gynecomastia, testicular hypoplasia, and decreased axillary hair due to destruction of normal pituitary tissue, which results in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. However, pituitary adenomas are rare during childhood, and mitral valve prolapse is not a typical feature of gigantism. Instead, patients would have broad hands/feet, coarse facial features, hyperhidrosis, hypertension, visual field defects, and/or headache.

B) INCORRECT:

In an adolescent with tall stature, a mitral valve prolapse click, and features suggestive of cognitive delay (e.g., poor scholastic performance), homocystinuria might be suspected. In this case, diagnostics should include urinalysis testing for increased urine homocysteine levels. However, gynecomastia, testicular hypoplasia, and decreased axillary hair are not features associated with this syndrome. Instead, other skeletal abnormalities such as arachnodactyly, chest wall deformities, hindfoot valgus, scoliosis, and/or kyphosis would be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

In a male adolescent with tall stature and a mitral valve prolapse click, Marfan syndrome or fragile X syndrome might be suspected. In this case, a PCR with Southern blot can be used to identify mutations in specific genes. However, neither of these conditions are typically associated with gynecomastia, testicular hypoplasia, or decreased axillary hair. Instead, Marfan syndrome would present with other skeletal findings such as arachnodactyly, chest wall deformities, hindfoot valgus, scoliosis, and/or kyphosis. Patients with fragile X syndrome would present with a long face, large ears, and large testicles (macroorchidism) at the time of puberty.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with tall stature, long extremities, and a mitral valve prolapse click, homocystinuria or Marfan syndrome might be suspected. Homocystinuria can also result in features of cognitive delay (e.g., poor scholastic performance). Both homocystinuria and Marfan syndrome can result in ectopia lentis, which is diagnosed by slit-lamp examination. However, gynecomastia, testicular hypoplasia, and decreased axillary hair are not features associated with these syndromes. Instead, other skeletal abnormalities such as arachnodactyly, chest wall deformities, hindfoot valgus, scoliosis and/or kyphosis would be seen.

E) CORRECT:

Karyotyping is used to identify the sex chromosome trisomy associated with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY). The extra X chromosome (Barr body) interferes with testicular function, leading to impaired testosterone production. Treatment consists of lifelong testosterone substitution.

F) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the wrist in this patient with Klinefelter syndrome would most likely show a bone age that is equal to or less than the chronological age. However, since a number of causes of tall stature are associated with normal bone age (e.g., familial tall stature, obesity, Marfan syndrome, pituitary gigantism) or delayed bone age (e.g., estrogen insensitivity syndrome), this is a nonspecific finding in a patient with tall stature. A more specific test is required to diagnose Klinefelter syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a eunuchoid growth pattern (tall, slim stature with long extremities), gynecomastia, reduced body hair, testicular hypoplasia, a mitral valve prolapse click, and poor scholastic performance (which might suggest cognitive delay). These features are consistent with the diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His parents are concerned that he has not had his growth spurt yet. As a child, he was consistently in the 60th percentile for height; now he is in the 25th percentile. He has a normal diet but says that “food often has no taste”. His classmates make fun of his short stature and high-pitched voice. As an infant, he had bilateral orchidopexy for cryptorchidism and a cleft palate repair. He is otherwise healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, axillary and pubic hair is sparse. His genital development is at Tanner stage 1. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia does manifest with hypogonadism in male individuals, which could explain the poor genital development in this patient. However, the associated lack of testosterone in this condition would typically cause gynecomastia, which is not seen in this patient. Furthermore, hyperprolactinemia is most commonly caused by a prolactinoma and therefore would likely manifest with additional features such as symptoms of mass effect (e.g., headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, diplopia).

B) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngioma could cause delayed onset of puberty. However, this patient has none of the classic symptoms associated with this diagnosis, such as visual field defects, hyperprolactinemia, or central diabetes insipidus.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism could cause delayed onset of puberty. However, it is associated with typical features such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, and hair loss, none of which are present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Klinefelter syndrome can manifest with delayed puberty in a male patient. However, a patient with Klinefelter syndrome would characteristically have a tall, slender frame and gynecomastia. Moreover, the additional features in this adolescent (impaired sense of smell, a history of cryptorchidism, and cleft palate) are not explained by Klinefelter syndrome, suggesting another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary hypogonadism would cause a delay in the development of secondary sexual characteristics in a male adolescent. It would also explain this patient's poor genital and testicular development. However, this patient's impaired sense of smell and history of cryptorchidism and cleft palate are not explained by this diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Kallmann syndrome is a rare, congenital form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism that develops as a result of deficient hypothalamic GnRH secretion. Patients typically present with delayed onset of puberty, an impaired sense of smell (due to disrupted neural migration from the olfactory bulbs to the hypothalamic preoptic nuclei), and a history of cryptorchidism and/or cleft palate. Diagnosis is clinical and further supported by findings of decreased GnRH, FSH, LH, estrogen or testosterone. Treatment consists of hormone replacement therapy during puberty and gonadotropins or pulsatile GnRH for the management of infertility in adults.

G) INCORRECT:

Constitutional delay of growth and puberty is a common cause of delayed puberty and would explain the delayed development of sexual characteristics in this adolescent. However constitutional delay of puberty is often associated with a similar history in the parents, which is not mentioned in this case. Moreover, impaired sense of smell and history of cryptorchidism and cleft palate would not typically be seen in constitutional delay and suggest another diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's altered sense of taste is likely a result of an impaired sense of smell.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not yet had her first menstrual period. Her mother had her first menstrual period at the age of 11 years. She participates in competitive gymnastics. The patient is at the 5th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 144/82 mm Hg. Examination shows a low posterior hairline and an unusually broad neck. Breast development is Tanner stage 1. Pelvic examination shows normal external female genitalia with scant pubic hair. Pelvic ultrasound shows small ovaries, sparse atretic follicles, and a normal-appearing uterus. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following are the most likely laboratory findings for this patient?



Follicle-stimulating hormone
Luteinizing hormone
Androgens
Estradiol



A
Decreased
Decreased
Decreased
Decreased


B
Normal
Normal
Normal
Normal


C
Normal
Increased
Increased
Normal


D
Increased
Increased
Decreased
Decreased


E
Increased
Increased
Increased
Increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The constellation of decreased FSH, LH, androgens, and estradiol can be seen in cases of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (e.g., pituitary tumors, excessive exercise, anorexia nervosa, Kallmann syndrome). Although this patient's participation in competitive sports may increase her risk of developing hypogonadotropic amenorrhea, her presentation with low posterior hairline, neck webbing, and small, atretic ovaries suggests a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary amenorrhea with normal levels of FSH, LH, androgen, and estradiol can be seen in female outflow tract disorders or genital tract anatomical abnormalities (e.g., imperforate hymen, absent vagina or uterus). However, this patient's presentation with normal external female genitalia and normal uterus makes these conditions unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased LH and androgen levels with normal estrogen and FSH levels are seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which can occasionally cause primary amenorrhea. However, patients with PCOS would not have atretic ovaries and delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics. Instead, enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts and features of hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism, acne vulgaris) would be expected.

D) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome is characterized by impaired ovarian growth and the subsequent development of streak ovaries and primary ovarian insufficiency. Affected individuals develop hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, which is characterized by elevated gonadotropin (FSH and LH) levels alongside decreased estrogen levels. Individuals with Turner syndrome also present with decreased androgen levels because nearly half of all androgen production in female individuals occurs in the ovaries.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated levels of FSH, LH, androgen, and estradiol are seen in patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS). Complete AIS can also manifest with primary amenorrhea in a patient with normal external female genitalia. However, complete AIS is characterized by normal breast development, complete absence of pubic hair (unlike the scant pubic hair in this patient), a blind vaginal loop on speculum examination, cryptorchid testes, and, typically, a tall stature. Hypertension would not be expected.
questions.hint: Primary amenorrhea and absent secondary sexual characteristics in a patient with short stature, a low posterior hairline, hypertension, and what appears to be a webbed neck are highly suggestive of Turner syndrome (45,XO karyotype).

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl comes to the physician for exertional leg pain. The pain began last week when she started jogging to lose weight. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a broad neck with bilateral excess skin folds that extend to the shoulders, as well as a low-set hairline and ears. There is an increased carrying angle when she fully extends her arms at her sides. Pulses are palpable in all extremities; lower leg pulses are delayed. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Gonadal dysgenesis and subsequent streak ovaries are characteristic findings in Turner syndrome. Failure of the germ cells to develop into ovaries results in deposition of hormonally inactive connective tissue. The absence of functional ovaries leads to estrogen and progesterone deficiencies, which cause delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, infertility, and osteoporosis.

B) INCORRECT:

An absent uterus on physical exam would be suggestive of Müllerian agenesis, which presents in females with karyotype 46,XX. It is not the genitourinary feature of Turner syndrome (45,X0). Müllerian agenesis is typically diagnosed during a gynecologic examination disclosing absence of the vagina (partial or total), cervix, and uterus.

C) INCORRECT:

Although mitral valve prolapse is seen in several genetic conditions, such as Marfan syndrome or Klinefelter syndrome, it is not a typical finding in Turner syndrome. Unlike Turner syndrome, Klinefelter syndrome and Marfan syndrome typically results in tall, slim stature and long extremities. Also, neither condition is characterized by coarctation of the aorta, webbed neck (excess skin folds), or cubitus valgus.

D) INCORRECT:

Triphalangeal thumb can occur as an isolated abnormality or in association with a genetic syndrome, such as Diamond-Blackfan anemia. This patient has some features that are consistent with this condition, such as low set ears and short stature, but it would not explain the difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower extremities or the delayed femoral pulses on exam. Moreover, Diamond-Blackfan anemia manifests in infancy or early childhood as a severe macrocytic anemia, of which there is no evidence in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A horseshoe kidney, not a horseshoe adrenal gland, is an anomaly seen in approx. 10% of patients with Turner syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's signs and symptoms of claudication with exertion and delayed femoral pulses are suggestive of aortic coarctation. Coarctation of the aorta, short stature, webbed neck (excess skin folds), and cubitus valgus (increased carrying angle) deformity are characteristic features of Turner syndrome.

questions.text:
At postpartum physical examination, a newborn is found to have male external genitalia. Scrotal examination shows a single palpable testicle in the right hemiscrotum. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis shows an undescended left testis, seminal vesicles, uterus, and fallopian tubes. Chromosomal analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely to be found in this newborn?



SRY-gene activity
Müllerian inhibitory factor (MIF)
Testosterone
Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)



A
↓
↓
↓
↓


B
Normal
normal
↑
↑


C
↓
↓
normal
normal


D
Normal
↓
normal
normal


E
Normal
normal
normal
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of decreased SRY-gene activity, MIF, testosterone, and DHT can be seen in Swyer syndrome, in which decreased SRY-gene activity results in nonfunctional gonads and thus no production of testosterone or MIF. Consequently, male genital organs do not develop, and the uterus and vagina develop despite the presence of XY chromosomes.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of increased testosterone and DHT in the setting of normal SRY-gene activity and MIF can be seen in androgen insensitivity syndrome. Unlike this patient, AIS typically presents with female external genitalia and male internal genitalia.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of normal testosterone and DHT in the setting of decreased SRY-gene activity and MIF is not possible because normal androgen levels require functioning testes, which need testis-determining factor (TDF) to develop. If the SRY gene is inactive, TDF will also not be synthesized.

D) CORRECT:

The SRY gene on chromosome Y is responsible for encoding the testis-determining factor (TDF) protein, which promotes the development of testis. In the testis, Sertoli cells produce MIF, and Leydig cells secrete testosterone. MIF leads to suppression of paramesonephric ducts, whereas testosterone converts the mesonephric ducts into male internal genitalia (i.e., seminal vesicle, epididymis, ejaculatory duct, ductus deferens). Testosterone is then converted to DHT (via 5α reductase), which is responsible for the development of male external genitalia (from genital tubercle, urethral folds, and genital swelling) and urogenital sinus differentiation (into bulbourethral glands and prostate gland). In the absence of MIF, the paramesonephric duct develops into female internal structures (i.e., fallopian tubes, uterus, upper portion of vagina), as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Components and derivatives of the undifferentiated gonads, mesonephric ducts, and paramesonephric ducts are labeled blue, yellow, and pink respectively. The undifferentiated gonads develop along the upper pathway in the presence of a functioning SRY gene, resulting in male internal and external genitalia. In the absence of the SRY gene, the lower pathway is followed, resulting in the formation of female internal and external genitalia

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased DHT in the setting of normal (or sometimes increased) testosterone can be seen in 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, which occurs in 46, XY patients who have male internal genitalia but present at birth with female external genitalia. Although male external genitalia can also develop, this first occurs during puberty when the increased synthesis of testosterone leads to virilization (i.e., phallic growth, testicular descent, development of male gender identity).
questions.hint: In the absence of hormones that trigger male sexual development, the default for sexual development is female internal and external genitalia. This newborn has normal male external genitalia and both male and female internal genitalia.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl comes to the physician because she has not yet had her period. She is at the 10th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Examination shows a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, a low posterior hairline, forearms angled 20° away from the body when fully extended, and shortened fourth metacarpals bilaterally. Sexual development is Tanner stage 1. Which of the following statements about this patient's fertility is most accurate?

choices.text: Pregnancy success rate with donor oocytes is similar to patients with primary ovarian failure
Administration of gonadotropins will increase the chances of conceiving
Impaired tubal ciliary function will prevent natural fertilization
The majority of patients become pregnant without medical assistance
Functional gametes and the absence of a uterus make surrogacy necessary

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The primary cause of infertility for women with Turner syndrome is ovarian dysgenesis (streak ovary). A lack of hormone production from defective ovaries leads to estrogen and progesterone deficiency and prevents the development of secondary sexual characteristics. Almost all women with Turner syndrome will require estrogen and progestin replacement therapy to stimulate puberty. With this supplementation, pregnancy can still be achieved using in vitro fertilization with donor oocytes. The rate of successful pregnancy with this method for women with Turner syndrome is similar to that for women with primary ovarian failure in general.

Patients with Turner syndrome who successfully achieve pregnancy using in vitro fertilization with oocyte donation are at significant risk for developing an aortic dissection during pregnancy and the postpartum period. A pre-existing cardiac condition in these patients is an absolute contraindication for pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Administration of gonadotropins (e.g., FSH and LH) does not increase the chances of conceiving in patients with Turner syndrome, as these patients already have elevated FSH and LH due to the lack of estrogen and progesterone production in the defective ovaries.

C) INCORRECT:

Infertility due to impaired fallopian tube ciliary function is seen in primary ciliary dyskinesia. Loss of functional cilia in the fallopian tubes makes it difficult for the fertilized oocyte to travel to the uterine body, which leads to reduced fertility and, rarely, ectopic pregnancies. Patients with Turner syndrome also have reduced fertility, but it is due to ovarian dysgenesis (streak ovary) rather than loss of ciliary function.

D) INCORRECT:

While it is possible for a patient with Turner syndrome to become pregnant without additional medical assistance, it is quite rare. Patients who achieve spontaneous pregnancy are more likely to show a less severe, mosaic genotype (45,XO/46,XX), in which case delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea are less common.

E) INCORRECT:

Functional gametes in the absence of a uterus characterize Müllerian agenesis. These patients often first present with primary amenorrhea, like women with Turner syndrome, but the presence of functional gonads allows for normal secondary sexual characteristics. Patients with Müllerian agenesis do not have short stature, shield chest, deviation of the forearm from the body (cubitus valgus), low posterior hairline, or shortened fourth metacarpals, which are all seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has delayed puberty as well as short stature, shield chest, deviation of the forearm from the body (cubitus valgus), a low posterior hairline, and shortened fourth metacarpals. These are all features of Turner syndrome.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because menarche has not yet occurred. She is at the 3rd percentile for height. Examination of a buccal mucosal scraping shows that some cells have a single dark inclusion consistent with the appearance of a Barr body attached to the nuclear membrane. Karyotyping shows 45 chromosomes in some neutrophils and 46 chromosomes in other neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's cytogenetic abnormality?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uniparental isodisomy is a form of uniparental disomy (UPD) caused by nondisjunction (during meiosis II) of identical homologous chromosomes from one parent. Most individuals with UPD have no phenotypic anomalies. Patients present with phenotypic anomalies only if the identical homologous chromosomes contain a recessive gene mutation or a gene silenced by genetic imprinting (e.g., Prader-Willi syndrome, Angelman syndrome). Unlike this patient, however, individuals with UPD have normal karyotypes.

B) CORRECT:

Complete 45,XO monosomy, which is the result of meiotic nondisjunction in gametes, is associated with the absence of a Barr body in all cells and is the most common karyotype in patients with Turner syndrome. However, in a significant number of individuals with Turner syndrome, monosomy in some but not all daughter cells (somatic mosaicism) is the underlying abnormality. This abnormality is caused by postzygotic mitotic nondisjunction, which is the failure of sister chromatids to separate during mitosis of an embryonic cell. Patients with Turner syndrome due to somatic mosaicism will have a 45,XO/46,XX karyotype (common) or a 45,XO/46,XY (rare). The clinical phenotype caused by somatic mosaicism is usually milder than in patients with complete 45,XO monosomy but patients with Turner syndrome and a 45,XO/46,XY karyotype are at increased risk of developing a gonadoblastoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Robertsonian translocation is an exchange of genes at the centromere of two acrocentric chromosomes, which renders a new chromosome made up of the two long arms and a small chromosome that is frequently lost. This leaves a karyotype with 45 chromosomes, as seen in this patient. However, her presentation is suggestive of Turner syndrome (loss of a nonacrocentric X chromosome), making Robertsonian translocation unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Nondisjunction during meiosis I is the failure of homologous chromosomes to separate during the first meiotic division of gametes. It is a cytogenetic abnormality that can cause Turner syndrome. However, this anomaly results in complete monosomy (45,XO) as opposed to mosaicism (45,XO/46,XX). Barr bodies would be absent in a patient with complete sex chromosomal monosomy.

E) INCORRECT:

Reciprocal translocation is a type of chromosomal rearrangement that involves exchange of genetic material between nonhomologous chromosomes. Translocations can be balanced (without loss of genetic material) or unbalanced (unequal exchange with extra or missing genes). Unlike this patient, most individuals with reciprocal translocations are phenotypically normal and have 46 chromosomes on karyotyping.
questions.hint: This patient has clinical features (primary amenorrhea, short stature) and a karyotype consistent with Turner syndrome (45,XO). A Barr body (lyonized X chromosome) would not be present in a cell with X chromosomal monosomy since the only X chromosome that is present in these cells would be transcriptionally active. This indicates that at least some cells have a 46,XX karyotype.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not attained menarche. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Breast development is Tanner stage 4, and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 1. Pelvic examination shows a blind vaginal pouch. This patient is most likely to have which of the following karyotypes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A 45,XO karyotype is seen in Turner syndrome, which can cause primary amenorrhea (due to ovarian dysgenesis). However, patients with Turner typically have impaired breast development and a short stature, unlike this patient with normal breast development and a normal height. Moreover, Turner syndrome would not explain the blind vaginal pouch, and other features characteristic of Turner syndrome (e.g., low hair-line, neck webbing, shield chest) are not present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with a 47,XYY karyotype are phenotypically male and present with features such as tall stature and mild learning disabilities. This phenotypically female patient is unlikely to have a 47,XYY karyotype.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with Mullerian agenesis would have a normal female karyotype (46,XX) and present with primary amenorrhea as well as a blind vaginal pouch. However, pubic hair development would not be delayed in Mullerian agenesis.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) are karyotypically male (46,XY). The Y chromosome results in the formation of the testes from the undifferentiated fetal gonad. However, the genital tubercle does not respond to testosterone in complete AIS, and masculinization of external genitalia does not occur. The uterus and upper third of the vagina do not develop because the anti-Mullerian hormone secreted by the testes causes Mullerian duct atresia. Androgen insensitivity also results in a failure of the cranial suspensory ligament to regress, meaning the testes remain in the abdomen or inguinal canal instead of the perineal region. Patients are born with female external genitalia and generally raised as females. At the time of puberty, axillary and pubic hair growth does not occur since cutaneous androgen receptors are also insensitive. Breast development occurs despite the absence of ovaries since aromatase in adipose tissue converts androgens produced by the inguinal testes to estradiol. LH levels are increased due to the lack of negative feedback by androgens on the androgen-insensitive pituitary. Testosterone levels will be increased due to stimulation of the Leydig cells of the intra-abdominal testes by increased LH levels.

E) INCORRECT:

A 47,XXY karyotype is seen in Klinefelter syndrome, which can cause breast development (gynecomastia) and impaired pubic hair growth. However, patients with Klinefelter syndrome would have male external genitalia at birth unlike this patient with female external genitalia.
questions.hint: Further testing will show elevated LH and testosterone levels.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she frequently experiences cramping and pain in her legs during school sports. She is at the 10th percentile for height. Her blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a high-arched palate with maloccluded teeth and a low posterior hairline. The patient has a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Pelvic examination shows normal external female genitalia with scant pubic hair. Without appropriate treatment, this patient is at the greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is one of the classic cardiac defects seen in patients with Noonan syndrome. Although Noonan syndrome is clinically similar to Turner syndrome (short stature, high arched palate, webbed neck, chest deformity), this patient presents with signs of aortic coarctation, which would not be consistent with Noonan syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Ovarian dysgenesis is one of the most common features of Turner syndrome. Since the ovaries are the predominant source of estrogen, many patients with Turner syndrome are estrogen deficient, which results in increased osteoclast activity, decreased osteoblast activity, and bone reabsorption. Patients with Turner syndrome are therefore at increased risk for osteoporosis and pathologic fractures. Almost all patients with Turner syndrome require exogenous estrogen and progesterone replacement to prevent complications of sex hormone deficiency.

Laboratory studies in patients with untreated Turner syndrome show hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, i.e. low estrogen, high follicle stimulating hormone, and high luteinizing hormone.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe acne is commonly seen in patients with a karyotype 47,XYY (double Y males). Unlike patients with Turner syndrome, which this patient likely has, patients with 47,XYY syndrome have a male phenotype, mildly delayed motor and language development, and, typically, tall stature due to excess growth hormone. Physical anomalies like those seen in this patient are rarely present.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperphagia is commonly seen in Prader-Willi syndrome. Although patients with Prader-Willi syndrome can also have short stature and gonadal dysfunction (resulting in delayed menarche), this patient lacks other features of Prader-Willi syndrome, e.g., intellectual disability, progressive obesity, abnormal facial features (e.g., almond-shaped eyes), and a history of hypotonia and feeding difficulty during infancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Superior lens dislocation is associated with Marfan syndrome and is caused by defects in the ciliary zonules. Although patients with Marfan syndrome also often have a high-arched palate and cardiac abnormalities, they typically have aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, and/or ascending aortic aneurysm rather than aortic coarctation. Furthermore, Marfan syndrome is associated with tall stature, long extremities, arachnodactyly, pectus deformity, and joint hypermobility, none of which is seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with Down syndrome are at increased risk of early-onset Alzheimer disease. Although patients with Down syndrome typically also have short stature and physical anomalies, this patient lacks the classic features of Down syndrome, which include intellectual disability and facial anomalies (upward slanting palpebral fissures, epicanthus). Low posterior hairline, shield chest, and signs of aortic coarctation are not features of Down syndrome.
questions.hint: This female patient presents with short stature, delayed puberty, a high-arched palate, maloccluded teeth, a low hairline, a broad chest, and signs of aortic coarctation (hypertension, lower extremity claudication). These features are consistent with Turner syndrome.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal examination. She has no history of significant medical illness. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent with a 10-week gestation. Cell-free fetal DNA testing shows a karyotype of 47,XXY. If the fetus's condition had not been diagnosed until puberty, which of the following sets of hormonal changes would most likely be found at that time?



Follicle-stimulating hormone
Luteinizing hormone
Testosterone
Estrogen



A
↑
↑
↓
↑


B
↓
↓
↓
↓


C
↑
↑
normal
normal


D
↑
↑
↑
↓


E
↓
↓
normal
↑
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome have testosterone deficiency beginning at puberty due to testicular dysgenesis. Decreased testosterone levels lead to a loss of the negative feedback loop to the hypothalamus and a compensatory increase in FSH and LH. Increased FSH levels stimulate aromatase synthesis, which leads to increased conversion of testosterone to estradiol. This hormonal imbalance manifests as gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, and a eunuchoid growth pattern. Additional features of Klinefelter syndrome include sparse body hair, azoospermia, and mitral valve prolapse.

B) INCORRECT:

This constellation of sex hormones is characteristic of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which is caused by insufficient release of GnRH (hypothalamus) or LH/FSH (pituitary), which leads to deficient levels of testosterone and estrogen. Causes of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism include intracranial tumors (e.g., craniopharyngioma, prolactinoma), infections, radiation, trauma, and genetic disorders (e.g., Kallmann syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with unilateral cryptorchidism have normal levels of peripheral sex hormones but increased FSH and LH. Cryptorchidism adversely affects Sertoli cell function, which leads to impaired spermatogenesis and decreased inhibin levels. Leydig cells are unaffected, so testosterone production remains normal. Decreased inhibin levels lead to persistently increased LH and FSH. Klinefelter syndrome manifests with a different pattern of sex hormone disturbance.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased gonadotropin levels in combination with increased testosterone and decreased estrogen levels are characteristic of aromatase deficiency. This condition leads to decreased estrogen production with a compensatory increase in FSH and LH (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism). Affected males have normal sexual differentiation, whereas females have ambiguous genitalia at birth and virilization and primary amenorrhea later in life. Klinefelter syndrome manifests with a different pattern of sex hormone disturbance.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased peripheral sex hormones and decreased central sex hormones are diagnostic of autonomous excessive sex hormone production. This condition can be caused by sex hormone-producing tumors (e.g., Leydig-cell tumor), McCune-Albright syndrome, some types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and exogenous hormone administration. Patients typically develop precocious puberty. Klinefelter syndrome presents with a different pattern of sex hormone disturbance
questions.hint: The 47,XXY karyotype is diagnostic of Klinefelter syndrome, which is one of the most common causes of male infertility.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because his parents are concerned about his persistently poor performance at school. He has had increased impulsivity and has difficulty making and keeping friends. On questioning, he reports that he is being bullied by his classmates for his high-pitched voice, thin build, and poor grades. He is at the 94th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows bilateral gynecomastia, sparse pubic hair, and long limbs compared with the trunk. Genital examination shows small, firm testes. Serum studies show increased levels of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone and a slightly decreased serum testosterone. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rather than an increased risk of developing prostate cancer, patients with Klinefelter syndrome have been found to have a significantly decreased incidence of and mortality from prostate cancer.

B) CORRECT:

Testicular hypoplasia in Klinefelter syndrome leads to decreased testosterone levels, which causes a loss of negative feedback on gonadotropins (e.g., LH, FSH). Elevated levels of FSH stimulate aromatase synthesis, which then stimulates the conversion of testosterone to estradiol. This leads to increased estrogen levels, one of the strongest predisposing factors of breast cancer. Compared with the general population, patients with Klinefelter syndrome have been found to have a 15- to 20-fold increased risk of developing breast cancer. Klinefelter syndrome also increases the risk of testicular and extragonadal germ cell tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

The risk of aortic dissection is increased in patients with Marfan syndrome due to an underlying connective tissue disorder. Patients have characteristically tall stature and marfanoid habitus; however, testicular hypoplasia, gynecomastia, and reduced body hair are not common presentations of Marfan syndrome. Moreover, Marfan syndrome does not cause hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

D) INCORRECT:

Inferior lens dislocation can be seen in patients with homocystinuria. In addition to ectopia lentis, patients with homocystinuria commonly present with tall stature and marfanoid habitus. Although this patient is at the 94th percentile for height, his laboratory findings of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and other physical examination findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1 increases the risk of developing neurofibromas and optic gliomas. Other characteristic features of NF type 1 include café-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules, tall stature, and mild-to-moderate cognitive delay. Although this patient's tall stature and poor school performance may support this diagnosis, he has no other features suggestive of NF type 1. Instead, his laboratory and other physical examination findings are consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which does not increase the risk of optic gliomas.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

F) INCORRECT:

Acute myeloid and lymphocytic leukemias are commonly associated with Down syndrome (DS). Although this patient's poor school performance may suggest an underlying mild cognitive delay, he lacks typical features of DS, such as short stature, upward-slanting palpebral fissures, a single transverse palmar crease, and extensive intellectual disability. Finally, the patient's other symptoms (such as delayed puberty, gynecomastia) and laboratory results are inconsistent with DS.
questions.hint: This patient's physical appearance, impulsivity, poor performance at school (a potential sign of cognitive delay), and laboratory results indicating hypergonadotropic hypogonadism are strongly suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has never menstruated. She is at the 15th percentile for weight and 45th percentile for height. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows facial hair, clitoromegaly, and coarse, curly pubic hair that extends to the inner surface of both thighs. She has no glandular breast tissue. Ultrasound shows inguinal testes but no uterus or ovaries. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The most common forms of sex chromosomal mosaicism are the 45,XO/46,XX and 45,XO/46,XY karyotypes. The clinical features vary depending on the proportion of cells with the 45,XO karyotype. Patients with a large number of 45,XO cells are phenotypically female and develop features of Turner syndrome such as primary amenorrhea, impaired breast development, and hypoplastic/absent ovaries. Hirsutism and clitoromegaly can also occur in patients with a 45XO/46,XY karyotype. However, patients would have other signs of Turner syndrome (e.g., webbing of the neck with a low hairline at the nape, intellectual disability, broad-based shoulders).

B) INCORRECT:

Sex chromosomal monosomy is the underlying pathophysiology of Turner syndrome, which may manifest with primary amenorrhea and impaired breast development. However, hirsutism is not usually present, and patients have female external genitalia but not clitoromegaly. Patients may also have webbing of the neck with a low hairline at the nape, short stature, cubitus valgus defect, broad shoulders, lymphedema, intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and/or renal anomalies. Although the ovaries may be absent in Turner syndrome (replaced by fibrous streaks), the uterus is usually present.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome are genetically male but phenotypically female. As in this patient, they present with primary amenorrhea because they have no uterus or ovaries, and ultrasound would show intraabdominal or inguinal testes, which could cause pain as they grow during puberty. Unlike this patient, patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome develop normally without clitoromegaly or pronounced body hair.

Unlike patients with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome, those with partial androgen insensitivity syndrome may be phenotypically female during childhood and develop clitoromegaly/micropenis and hirsutism during puberty.

D) INCORRECT:

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which may manifest with clitoromegaly, hirsutism, and impaired breast development. However, patients usually have precocious puberty with irregular menstrual cycles, not primary amenorrhea. Both the uterus as well as ovaries are present on ultrasound. Patients would also have hyperpigmentation, acne, and/or evidence of growth restriction.

E) INCORRECT:

Aromatase deficiency in a child who is phenotypically female may manifest at puberty with primary amenorrhea, clitoromegaly/micropenis, impaired breast development, and hirsutism. However, ultrasound would show a uterus and ovaries since these patients are karyotypically female (XX). Karyotypically male (XY) patients with aromatase deficiency present with fully developed male external genitalia. Patients would also typically have a tall stature.

F) INCORRECT:

Isolated agenesis of the Mullerian ducts would result in primary amenorrhea and an absent uterus on ultrasonography. Although the ovaries would be present, clitoromegaly, hirsutism, and impaired breast development would not be expected in Mullerian agenesis. Instead, patients have a blind vaginal pouch due to vaginal atresia.

G) CORRECT:

The enzyme 5-α reductase catalyzes the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). Because DHT is required for the in-utero differentiation and development of external male genitalia and the prostate, these organs are underdeveloped in individuals with 5-α reductase deficiency. At birth, most affected individuals have female-appearing external genitalia, although a range of presentations is possible, including pseudovaginal perineoscrotal hypospadias. During adolescence, the fully developed testes produce increased levels of testosterone, resulting in masculinization of the external genitalia and the development of male secondary sexual characteristics such as body hair (which can be mistaken for hirsutism). Uterus, ovaries, and glandular breast tissue are absent because the patient is karyotypically male (XY).

The diagnosis is confirmed by a genetic test detecting mutation of the SRD5A2 gene on chromosome 2p. In patients with a male gender identity, testosterone supplementation with phalloplasty and orchidopexy can be considered. Patients with female gender identity should be offered gonadectomy followed by estrogen substitution therapy upon completion of longitudinal growth. Regardless of the patient's gender identity, treatment should be provided according to their individual wishes and medical needs and should follow a multidisciplinary approach that includes psychological counseling.
Image Description:

Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.
questions.hint: The masculinization seen in this patient is the result of increased testosterone synthesis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of his sense of smell. Two days ago, his mother found that he had left the gas on in the kitchen, and he was unable to smell the odor of the gas. As a child, he was consistently in the 40th percentile for height; now he is in the 15th percentile. He had bilateral orchidopexy for cryptorchidism as an infant. The patient is unable to identify several common odors when presented with them. Physical examination shows sparse axillary and pubic hair and Tanner stage 1 genitals. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constitutional delay of growth and puberty is a common cause of delayed puberty and would explain the delayed development of sexual characteristics in this adolescent. However, constitutional delay of puberty is often associated with a similar history in the parents, which is not mentioned in this case. Moreover, anosmia and a history of cryptorchidism would not typically be seen in constitutional delay.

B) INCORRECT:

A craniopharyngioma can delay the onset of puberty by compressing the pituitary stalk and interfering with pituitary function. However, this patient has none of the classical symptoms associated with this diagnosis, such as visual field defects, hyperprolactinemia, or central diabetes insipidus.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia does present with hypogonadism in males, which could explain the poor genital development in this patient. However, the associated lack of testosterone in this condition would typically cause gynecomastia, which is not seen in this patient. Furthermore, hyperprolactinemia is most commonly caused by a prolactinoma and therefore would likely present with additional features such as symptoms of mass effect (e.g., headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, diplopia).

D) CORRECT:

Kallmann syndrome, caused by impaired migration of GnRH neurons during embryogenesis, typically manifests with delayed-onset puberty, an impaired sense of smell (hyposmia or anosmia), and a history of cryptorchidism and/or cleft palate. This patient presents with most of these classical features. This syndrome is a rare, congenital form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and causes a delayed onset of puberty due to deficient hypothalamic GnRH secretion.

E) INCORRECT:

Klinefelter syndrome is a sex chromosome trisomy (XXY) that can present with delayed puberty in a male patient. However, a patient with Klinefelter syndrome would characteristically have a tall, slender frame and gynecomastia. Moreover, the additional features in this adolescent (anosmia and history of cryptorchidism) are not explained by Klinefelter syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism, a condition of decreased thyroxine production, could cause a delayed onset of puberty. However, it is associated with typical features such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, and hair loss, none of which are present in this patient.
questions.hint: Other findings often associated with this condition are cleft palate and unilateral renal agenesis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of right testicular pain. At the age of 6 months, he was treated for hypospadias and cryptorchidism. Physical examination shows a rubbery, enlarged right testicle. Orchidectomy is performed. Results of a biopsy specimen show multiple well-developed seminiferous tubules and primordial follicles. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An increased radio-femoral delay is suggestive of aortic coarctation, which can be seen in patients with Turner syndrome (45, XO). However, this patient has a predominantly male phenotype, which rules out Turner syndrome. His biopsy findings are suggestive of another difference of sex development that is not characterized by an increased radio-femoral delay.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased eye contact is seen in a myriad of disorders, including child abuse, autism spectrum disorder, fragile X syndrome, and double Y male individuals (47,XYY karyotype). This patient's biopsy, however, is suggestive of a difference of sex development that is not typically characterized by decreased eye contact.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased placental alkaline phosphatase would be seen in testicular tumors such as seminomas. This patient's history of cryptorchidism is a major risk factor for seminomas, and an enlarged testicle on physical examination would support such a diagnosis. However, his right testicular pain is not consistent with the usually painless presentation of germ cell tumors, and his biopsy findings are not consistent with the “fried-egg” appearance characteristic of seminomas. Thus, his symptoms are more likely due to a difference of sex development.

In contrast, testicular embryonal carcinomas, which belong to the group of nonseminoma tumors, are aggressive tumors with early metastases and can indeed manifest with testicular pain.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of testicular tumor (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is a solid growing tumor (green overlay) that consists of spermatogonia-like cells with clear to slightly granulated cytoplasm and large nuclei (white arrowheads). A tumor-associated lymphocytic infiltrate is visible (white overlay). For comparison, a normal testicular tubule (black outline) with normal spermatogonia (black arrowheads) is shown.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

A history of cryptorchidism and hypo- or anosmia in a young man would be highly suggestive of Kallmann syndrome. However, patients with this rare disorder are usually diagnosed earlier due to delayed puberty, and hypospadias is not a typical manifestation of Kallmann syndrome. This patient's biopsy is suggestive of a difference of sex development that is not characterized by decreased smell perception.

E) CORRECT:

Ovotesticular disorder is a rare difference of sex development characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues. Most patients with ovotesticular disorder have a female karyotype (46,XX), but approx. 10% of affected individuals have a male karyotype (46,XY) with a predominantly male phenotype, as seen here.
