Affected individuals typically have ambiguous genitalia, and infertility is common. Patients with a male karyotype typically also present with hypospadias and cryptorchidism at birth and increased glandular breast tissue (gynecomastia) during puberty due to the production of estrogen and progesterone in functional ovarian tissue.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a gonadal biopsy specimen (H&E stain; intermediate power magnification)

The image shows an area on the border between ovarian and testicular parenchyma. Primordial follicles (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen in the ovarian parenchyma on the left, while primitive seminiferous tubules (examples indicated by blue overlay) can be seen in the testicular parenchyma on the right.

The combination of ovarian and testicular tissue in the same biopsy specimen is diagnostic for ovotestis.
questions.hint: The biopsy contains both testicular tissue (seminiferous tubules) and ovarian tissue (primordial follicles).

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. He recently stopped attending his swim classes. The patient is at the 97th percentile for height and the 50th percentile for weight. Examination shows decreased facial hair, bilateral breast enlargement, and long extremities. Genital examination shows scant pubic hair, small testes, and a normal-sized penis. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following karyotypes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The karyotype 47,XYY is characteristic for XYY syndrome (or double Y syndrome), which is a sex chromosome disorder associated with tall stature in males. Affected individuals, however, are phenotypically normal and would not present with gynecomastia, reduced body hair, and testicular hypoplasia. Double Y syndrome is furthermore associated with severe acne in adolescence, learning disabilities, and autism spectrum disorders, none of which are reported here.

B) INCORRECT:

The karyotype 46,XY describes a normal male karyotype. This patient presents with signs and symptoms of Klinefelter syndrome, which is caused by a sex chromosome abnormality. Conditions associated with disorders of sex development despite a normal male karyotype include androgen insensitivity syndrome, 5α-reductase deficiency, and Swyer syndrome. Affected individuals are typically born with ambiguous genitalia or genitalia inconsistent with their chromosomal sex, which is not seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

The karyotype 46,XX/46,XY describes a sex chromosome mosaicism associated with ovotesticular disorder of sex development. This rare condition is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue (“ovotestes”). With the male karyotype, this condition may cause gynecomastia in adolescence. However, further features include ambiguous genitalia, hypospadias, and cryptorchidism at birth, as well as recurrent groin or scrotal pain, and testicular enlargement following the onset of puberty, none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, ovotesticular disorder is not associated with eunuchoid body shape and reduced body hair.

D) INCORRECT:

Turner syndrome, which is associated with a 45,XO karyotype, should be suspected in adolescent girls who present with primary amenorrhea, delayed puberty, or short stature. Further features include a webbed neck, shield chest with wide-set nipples, and cardiovascular abnormalities (e.g., coarctation of the aorta), none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, Turner syndrome is inconsistent with this patient's male phenotype.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome most commonly have the karyotype 47,XXY (caused by nondisjunction of sex chromosomes during meiosis of parental germ cells). Less common karyotypes include 48,XXXY and 48,XXYY. Diagnosis is primarily clinical and is typically made following the onset of puberty when testicular dysgenesis and subsequent testosterone deficiency become clinically apparent, as seen here. Karyotyping is then performed to provide a definitive diagnosis. Treatment of Klinefelter syndrome consists of life-long testosterone substitution.

F) INCORRECT:

The karyotype 45,XO/46,XX describes a sex chromosome mosaicism associated with Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome should be suspected in adolescent girls who present with primary amenorrhea, delayed puberty, or short stature. Further features include a webbed neck, shield chest with wide-set nipples, and cardiovascular abnormalities (e.g., coarctation of the aorta), none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, Turner syndrome is inconsistent with this patient's male phenotype.
questions.hint: This patient's eunuchoid growth pattern (tall stature with long extremities), gynecomastia, reduced body hair, and testicular hypoplasia are consistent with Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she is concerned that her daughter has not started puberty yet. The daughter reports that she is shorter than most of her peers at school and that she has not had her menstrual period. She is at the 15th percentile for height and the 10th percentile for weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows absent breast development. Pelvic examination shows normal external female genitalia. There is sparse pubic hair. Serum studies show an elevated FSH and LH and undetectable estradiol. Ultrasonography shows a small uterus, fallopian tubes, and streak ovaries. Chromosomal analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype. A defect in which of the following processes during embryogenesis best explains this patient's condition?

choices.text: Release of testosterone from Leydig cells
Production of androstenedione in adrenal cortex
Release of Mullerian inhibitory factor from Sertoli cells
Expression of testis-determining factor on SRY gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The release of testosterone from Leydig cells in the testes during embryogenesis stimulates the differentiation of the mesonephric ducts into male internal genitalia. A defect in this process could explain why this genotypically male patient lacks male internal genitalia and why LH levels are elevated (lack of negative feedback through testosterone). However, Leydig cell dysfunction does not explain the persistence of paramesonephric duct products (female internal genitalia) seen in this patient. Moreover, patients with this condition typically have normal FSH levels because the secretion of inhibin B from Sertoli cells is not affected.

B) INCORRECT:

The enzyme placental aromatase converts androgens to estrogens. In aromatase deficiency, serum testosterone is increased and serum estrogen is decreased. Affected individuals can present with normal internal female genitalia, delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, all of which are seen in this patient. However, such individuals have a 46,XX karyotype, are typically born with ambiguous external genitalia, and undergo virilization at the onset of puberty (due to high testosterone levels). In patients with a 46,XY karyotype (like this patient), aromatase deficiency does not affect normal sex development.

C) INCORRECT:

The enzyme 5-alpha-reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which triggers the differentiation of the genital tubercle and urogenital sinus into male external genitalia and the prostate gland during embryogenesis. A defect in this process could explain why this genotypically male patient has no male external genitalia. Patients with 5-alpha-reductase deficiency are born with female or ambiguous external genitalia. However, this condition does not explain the persistence of paramesonephric duct products (female internal genitalia) seen in this patient. Moreover, affected individuals undergo virilization in puberty when testosterone synthesis increases.
Image Description:

Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.

D) INCORRECT:

The production of androstenedione in the adrenal cortex provides the precursor hormone for the synthesis of testosterone and estradiol. Disturbed production of androstenedione is seen in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Like this patient, affected individuals are genotypically male and present with female external genitalia, delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and a lack of secondary sex characteristics. However, patients with this deficiency have additional characteristics, including a blind-ending vagina, intraabdominal testes, and hypertension and hypokalemia (due to mineralocorticoid excess), none of which are seen here. Moreover, this patient has sparse pubic hair, which is evidence that androgen production in the adrenal cortex is not defective.

E) INCORRECT:

The release of Mullerian inhibitory factor (MIF) from Sertoli cells suppresses the differentiation of the paramesonephric ducts into female internal genitalia during embryogenesis. A defect in this process is seen in the rare persistent Mullerian duct syndrome. Like this patient, affected individuals have a 46,XY karyotype and female internal genitalia due to decreased MIF levels. However, patients additionally have male external and internal genitalia, which are not seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

The fusion and differentiation of the paramesonephric ducts leads to the development of the female internal genitalia (except ovaries). A defect in this process is seen in Mullerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome), which manifests with primary amenorrhea in patients with female external genitalia. However, unlike this patient, affected individuals typically lack fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and parts of the vagina. Furthermore, patients with Mullerian agenesis have a 46,XX karyotype and functioning ovaries, which leads to normal estrogen levels with breast development and normal LH and FSH levels, whereas this patient has a 46,XY karyotype, streak ovaries, and a disturbed hormonal axis.

G) CORRECT:

A defect in the expression of the testis-determining factor (TDF) due to a dysfunctional SRY gene in XY gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome) prevents the differentiation of the gonads into testes in the 8th week of embryogenesis. In the normal development of a male embryo, the testes produce Mullerian inhibitory factor (by Sertoli cells), testosterone (by Leydig cells), and dihydrotestosterone, which leads to the development of male internal genitalia from the mesonephric ducts and male external genitalia. As seen here, the lack of these substances leads to the development of female internal genitalia from the paramesonephric ducts and female external genitalia.

Instead of functioning gonads, individuals with XY gonadal dysgenesis have streak gonads that do not produce sex hormones. The subsequent estrogen deficiency manifests with primary amenorrhea and delayed puberty (persistently small physique, missing development of secondary sex characteristics). Lifelong estrogen and progestogen substitution enables functional maturation with a regular menstrual cycle.
Image Description:

Components and derivatives of the undifferentiated gonads, mesonephric ducts, and paramesonephric ducts are labeled blue, yellow, and pink respectively. The undifferentiated gonads develop along the upper pathway in the presence of a functioning SRY gene, resulting in male internal and external genitalia. In the absence of the SRY gene, the lower pathway is followed, resulting in the formation of female internal and external genitalia
questions.hint: The presence of streak ovaries and hypergonadotropic hypogonadism in a phenotypically female but genotypically male individual is consistent with XY gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome).

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination one week after starting treatment with an oral antibiotic for uncomplicated cystitis. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and has not had her first menstrual period yet. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She is 140 cm (4 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (119 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a broad chest, a low-set posterior hairline, and several pigmented nevi on her body. Ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis shows fusion of the kidneys at the lower poles, a small uterus, and fibrous ovaries. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy is used to evaluate thyroid nodules or detect ectopic thyroid tissue. Since patients with Turner syndrome have an increased risk of autoimmune hypothyroidism (Hashimoto thyroiditis), TSH and T4 levels should be regularly monitored. However, this patient has no history of thyroid nodules and thyroid scintigraphy is not indicated for monitoring thyroid function.

B) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome is associated with a variety of cardiac anomalies, most commonly bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of the aorta. Because these anomalies increase the risk of early death, regular cardiac assessment with cardiac MRI or transthoracic echocardiography is recommended to detect and monitor structural anomalies. Patients with Turner syndrome should also receive regular screening for other commonly associated conditions, such as hypertension, hypothyroidism, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal biopsy may be indicated in patients with suspected glomerulonephritis or unexplained acute kidney injury. Although Turner syndrome is commonly associated with congenital renal anomalies, such as horseshoe kidney, screening for these conditions is performed with renal ultrasonography. Renal biopsy is not currently indicated in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammography is used for the early detection of breast cancer. Individuals with Turner syndrome, which this patient most likely has, do not have an increased risk of developing breast cancer compared to the general population. Therefore, mammography is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Nuclear bone scintigraphy is used to detect and evaluate bone injuries, joint conditions, and bone malignancies. Because patients with Turner syndrome have an increased risk of osteoporosis, periodic monitoring of bone mineral density (BMD) is indicated. However, BMD is monitored with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry rather than nuclear bone scintigraphy.
questions.hint: Hypertension, short stature, low-set posterior hairline, shield chest, and numerous pigmented nevi in a patient with a history of primary amenorrhea suggests Turner syndrome. Horseshoe kidney and streak gonads, both of which are seen here, are common findings in individuals with this condition.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. She was born at term to a 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. There is no family history of serious illness. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for weight and length. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows female external genitalia with clitoromegaly. Palpation of the inguinal area discloses bilateral firm masses. Pelvic ultrasonography shows no uterus or ovaries. Serum concentrations of luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, estradiol, and testosterone are within the reference ranges. The newborn's karyotype is 46,XY. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aromatase deficiency (AD) in karyotypically male (XY) patients can manifest with cryptorchidism (i.e., palpable inguinal masses), as seen here, but these patients have normal male external genitalia. Moreover, patients with AD have increased testosterone and decreased estrogen levels, whereas this patient has normal levels. Ambiguous external genitalia (e.g., clitoromegaly) at birth is a feature of AD in karyotypically female (XX) patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is characterized by a male karyotype (XY), female phenotype, clitoromegaly (in the partial type of AIS), cryptorchidism (e.g., palpable inguinal masses), and absent uterus and ovaries on ultrasound, all of which are seen in this patient. However, patients with AIS typically have increased levels of LH, FSH, estradiol, and testosterone, whereas this patient has normal levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Kallmann syndrome (KS) in karyotypically male patients (XY) can manifest with cryptorchidism (i.e., palpable inguinal masses), which is seen here. However, karyotypically male patients with KS have predominantly male external genitalia; microphallus can occur in these patients, but predominantly female external genitalia with clitoromegaly, as seen here, would not be expected. In addition, patients with KS have decreased levels of FSH, LH, and testosterone, whereas this patient has normal levels.

D) CORRECT:

Five-alpha-reductase deficiency (5-ARD) results in decreased levels of dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a hormone responsible for the formation of male external genitalia during embryogenesis. In the absence of DHT, karyotypically male (XY) patients are born with undervirilized male external genitalia. The condition has variable expressivity; at birth, the genitalia can vary in appearance from female external genitalia with or without clitoromegaly to male external genitalia with microphallus and/or hypospadias. Patients with female external genitalia are diagnosed at puberty when virilization occurs, while those with clitoromegaly, microphallus, or hypospadias are usually diagnosed at birth. The development of internal genitalia is unaffected in 5-ARD, and karyotypically male patients have testes (as intraabdominal or inguinal masses). Patients with 5-ARD have usually normal levels of testosterone, estrogen, FSH, and LH because of an intact hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing.

Management requires multidisciplinary care and is dependent on the time of diagnosis and the appearance of the genitalia. Patients who are diagnosed at birth or infancy often undergo male gender-affirming treatment. The treatment is more complex for patients who are diagnosed at puberty because these patients have typically been raised as females, and psychosocial counseling is required before any gender-affirming treatment takes place.
Image Description:

Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.

E) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 3 (17β-HSD3) is a rare congenital condition that results in impaired conversion of androstenedione to testosterone. In karyotypically male newborns, the deficiency is clinically indistinguishable from this patient's condition. However, while this patient's testosterone level is normal, patients with 17β-HSD3 deficiency have low testosterone levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of 21-hydroxylase in karyotypically female (XX) patients can manifest with clitoromegaly. However, pelvic ultrasound usually shows the presence of a uterus and ovaries, which is not the case in this patient. Additionally, karyotypically male (XY) patients with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically have normal male external genitalia at birth and palpable testes in the scrotum, neither of which are seen here. Moreover, testosterone levels are elevated in patients with 21-hydroxylase deficiency, whereas this patient has normal testosterone levels.
questions.hint: If this condition is left untreated, this patient will develop male secondary sexual characteristics (e.g., body hair, voice deepening) and further virilization of the external genitalia during puberty, caused by increased testosterone synthesis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman reports amenorrhea and absent sexual development. She has never had a menstrual period, breast development, or growth of pubic hair. She takes no medications. She was born at term with no complications, has received appropriate immunizations, and reports doing well in school. Her mother reached menarche at age 13 (and has had regular menstrual cycles since then), and her 14-year-old sister started menstruating recently.
The patient’s current height is 140 cm (below the third percentile), her weight is 45 kg (fifth percentile), and her BMI is 23. She has no axillary or pubic hair, and her breast development is consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 1. She has atrophic vaginal mucosa; the cervix is present.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Funduscopy is not likely to be diagnostic in a patient when the findings are consistent with Turner syndrome. A pituitary mass can lead to papilledema detectable by funduscopy, but a pituitary mass sufficient to cause papilledema and growth failure would likely also be associated with several endocrine deficiencies and visual disturbance.

B) INCORRECT:

Blood estradiol level results are likely to be abnormal in low-estrogen states, but abnormal findings on this test are not specific to Turner syndrome or to other causes of primary amenorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Progestin-withdrawal test results are likely to be abnormal in low-estrogen states, but abnormal findings on this test are not specific to Turner syndrome or to other causes of primary amenorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the FGFR1 gene lead to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, but not short stature.

E) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome is characterized by short stature and dysmorphic features, including a square chest, a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and a short fourth metacarpal bone. The characteristic features can be subtle but can also include a low posterior hairline, misshapen or rotated ears, and a narrow palate with crowded teeth. Affected patients may also have abnormalities in organogenesis, including coarctation, aortic dissection, and ovarian insufficiency (streak ovaries). Most patients with Turner syndrome have normal intelligence.

Patients with Turner syndrome occasionally present as teenagers because they have failed to menstruate or develop secondary sexual characteristics. The diagnosis is established by a karyotype that shows only one sex chromosome (45, X) in all cells or in only some cells (mosaicism).

Key learning point: The most appropriate test for Turner syndrome is a karyotype.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents for evaluation of primary amenorrhea. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She reports that she is not sexually active.
On physical examination, she is 132 cm tall and weighs 49 kg. Her blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute. She has a webbed neck without thyromegaly. She has a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Breast development and pubic hair are consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2. Cardiac auscultation reveals an early systolic ejection click.
Which one of the following cardiac anomalies is most likely to be found on an echocardiogram in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dextrocardia is a condition in which the heart is positioned toward the right chest and is associated with a right-sided point of maximal impulse on physical examination. It is not associated with Turner syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot can be present in Down’s syndrome, which is characterized by upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, flat facial profile, protruding tongue, dysplasia of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger, excessive skin at the base of the neck, transverse palmar crease, and widely spaced first and second toes.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's history and physical findings are consistent with Turner syndrome, a condition characterized by ovarian dysgenesis and short stature in females with a 45,X chromosomal constitution. Typical physical features associated with Turner syndrome include short stature, webbed neck, lymphedema, low posterior hairline, cubitus valgus, micrognathia, broad chest with hypoplastic nipples, and shortened fourth metacarpals. Turner syndrome may manifest in childhood with short stature or in adolescence with delayed puberty and primary or secondary amenorrhea.

About 40% of patients with Turner syndrome have hypertension, and 20% to 50% have cardiovascular anomalies, typically involving the left side of the heart. Bicuspid aortic valve is the most common malformation, occurring in up to 30% of patients, followed by coarctation of the aorta, which occurs in 18% of patients. Other associated cardiac conditions include mitral valve prolapse, partial anomalous pulmonary venous drainage, and hypoplastic left heart syndrome. Bicuspid aortic valve may manifest with an early systolic ejection click, but echocardiography or cardiac MRI should be used for definitive diagnosis.

Bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, and hypertension are risk factors for aortic root dilation, which can predispose to aortic dissection. Thus, the diagnosis of these cardiac anomalies necessitates close follow-up for aortic root dilatation and should prompt education of patients and families regarding possible signs and symptoms of aortic dissection.

Key learning point: The most common cardiac anomaly associated with Turner syndrome is bicuspid aortic valve, followed by coarctation of the aorta.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is the most common cardiac defect associated with Noonan syndrome, which is characterized by low-set ears, hypertelorism, downward slanting eyes, pectus excavatum, and poor growth. Although Turner syndrome and Noonan syndrome have previously been categorized as male and female versions of a similar disease, presumably secondary to some crossover in facial and chest features, such a categorization is a misnomer.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's history and physical findings are consistent with Turner syndrome. About 40% of patients with Turner syndrome have hypertension, and 20% to 50% have cardiovascular anomalies, typically involving the left side of the heart. Coarctation of the aorta occurs in 18% of patients with Turner syndrome. Bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, and hypertension are risk factors for aortic root dilation, which can predispose to aortic dissection. Thus, the diagnosis of these cardiac anomalies necessitates close follow-up for aortic root dilatation and should prompt education of patients and families regarding possible signs and symptoms of aortic dissection.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents for evaluation of primary amenorrhea. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She reports that she is not sexually active.
On physical examination, she is 132 cm tall (<1st percentile) and weighs 49 kg (27th percentile). Her blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute. She has a webbed neck without thyromegaly. She has a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Breast and pubic hair development are both consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 1. Cardiac auscultation reveals an early systolic ejection click.
Which one of the following cardiac anomalies is most likely to be found on an echocardiogram in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is the most common cardiac defect associated with Noonan syndrome, which is characterized by low-set ears, hypertelorism, downward slanting eyes, pectus excavatum, and poor growth. Although Turner syndrome and Noonan syndrome have previously been categorized as male and female versions of a similar disease, presumably secondary to some crossover in facial and chest features, such a categorization is a misnomer.

B) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta is the second most common cardiac anomaly in patients with Turner syndrome. A different cardiac anomaly is more common in these patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot can be present in Down’s syndrome, which is characterized by upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, flat facial profile, protruding tongue, dysplasia of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger, excessive skin at the base of the neck, transverse palmar crease, and widely spaced first and second toes.

D) INCORRECT:

Dextrocardia is a condition in which the heart is positioned toward the right chest and is associated with a right-sided point of maximal impulse on physical examination. It is not associated with Turner syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's history and physical findings are consistent with Turner syndrome, a condition characterized by ovarian dysgenesis and short stature in females with a 45,X chromosomal constitution. Typical physical features associated with Turner syndrome include short stature, webbed neck, lymphedema, low posterior hairline, cubitus valgus, micrognathia, broad chest with hypoplastic nipples, and shortened fourth metacarpals. Turner syndrome may manifest in childhood with short stature or in adolescence with delayed puberty and primary or secondary amenorrhea.

About 40% of patients with Turner syndrome have hypertension, and 20% to 50% have cardiovascular anomalies, typically involving the left side of the heart. Bicuspid aortic valve is the most common malformation, occurring in up to 30% of patients, followed by coarctation of the aorta, which occurs in 18% of patients. Other associated cardiac conditions include mitral valve prolapse, partial anomalous pulmonary venous drainage, and hypoplastic left heart syndrome. Bicuspid aortic valve may manifest with an early systolic ejection click, but echocardiography or cardiac MRI should be used for definitive diagnosis.

Bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, and hypertension are risk factors for aortic root dilation, which can predispose to aortic dissection. Thus, the diagnosis of these cardiac anomalies necessitates close follow-up for aortic root dilatation and should prompt education of patients and families regarding possible signs and symptoms of aortic dissection.

Key learning point: The most common cardiac anomaly associated with Turner syndrome is bicuspid aortic valve, followed by coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought in by his mother, who is concerned after a recent meeting with his kindergarten teacher. The teacher noted that he is quiet, does not get along well with his peers, tells stories that are not as complex as his peers’, and seems to mix up his verb tenses. His mother reports that he did not start talking until he was 21 months old but then seemed to catch up. His prior hearing tests have been normal.
On physical examination, his weight and height are at the 70th and 97th percentile for age, respectively. He is normocephalic, and his eyes and ears are normally placed. His cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Genitourinary examination reveals male genitalia consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 1 with micropenis; the testes cannot be palpated in the scrotal sac.
During a brief screening, the boy is unable to sing the alphabet song past the letter F, does not know his home address, and confuses his past and present verb tenses.
What type of hormone-replacement therapy is this patient most likely to require in the future?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's genitourinary findings, tall stature, and reported delay in language are suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of at least one extra X chromosome (karyotype 47,XXY). Klinefelter syndrome affects 1 in 500 to 1000 males but is often undetected in childhood, with only an estimated 10% of affected patients diagnosed before puberty. Men may be diagnosed as part of an azospermia workup. Klinefelter syndrome can be diagnosed with chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis in the prenatal period, but these are not common methods of diagnosis.

Boys with Klinefelter syndrome may have genitourinary abnormalities such as cryptorchidism, hypospadias, and micropenis. After puberty, they typically have decreased body hair, gynecomastia, a eunuchoid appearance, and infertility. They are also at increased risk for developing breast cancer, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, diabetes, systemic lupus erythematosus, and osteoporosis in adulthood.

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome typically benefit from androgen-replacement therapy. If the syndrome is diagnosed early enough, testosterone therapy can be started before the beginning of puberty to promote the development of male secondary sex characteristics.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a male patient who exhibits tall stature, language delay, cryptorchidism, and micropenis is Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY).

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome do not typically have adrenal insufficiency or panhypopituitarism and thus would not benefit from cortisol replacement.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism, but this condition is not associated with Klinefelter syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Growth hormone is not needed in the setting of Klinefelter syndrome, as these patients tend to be taller than average.

E) INCORRECT:

Estrogen-replacement therapy is not beneficial in patients with Klinefelter syndrome because these patients typically have low testosterone levels, not low estrogen levels. Furthermore, such therapy would likely worsen a patient's gynecomastia and increase his risk for breast cancer.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl who is new to your practice expresses concern that she has never had a menstrual period or experienced breast development. She was born at term with no complications, has received appropriate immunizations, reports doing well in school, and currently takes no medications. Her mother reached menarche at age 13 and has had regular menstrual cycles since then. She has one sister, who is 13 years old and recently started menstruating.
The patient’s current height is 140 cm (lower than the third percentile), her weight is 40.5 kg (about the fifth percentile), and her BMI is 20.7 (about the 50th percentile). Her examination is significant for low-set ears, and she wears glasses. She has pectoral adiposity without true glandular breast tissue and is between sexual maturity ratings (Tanner stages) 3 and 4 for pubic hair.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methylation studies would be diagnostic for Prader-Willi Syndrome, which can manifest with short stature but usually in combination with severe obesity and hypogonadism. Affected patients typically have failure to thrive and hypotonia at birth, developmental delay and intellectual disability, and small hands and feet.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of Müllerian structures is used to evaluate for Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, a condition that is associated with normal gonadotropin function but in which the uterus, cervix, and vagina may not form properly. Although patients with this syndrome often present with amenorrhea in their mid- to late teens (like the case patient did), they would have normal breast development and adrenarche.

C) INCORRECT:

An adrenocorticotropin hormone (ACTH) stimulation test would be used to evaluate for adrenal disorders, but such disorders are unlikely in this case. Although patients with congenital adrenal hypoplasia (which is due to a defective adrenal cortical zone) have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, they typically present in early infancy with adrenal failure. Patients with congenital adrenal hyperplasia may present with early-onset adrenarche that can progress to central precocious puberty, not hypogonadism.

D) INCORRECT:

Blood estradiol levels are likely to be low in this clinical scenario but would not help diagnose the cause of the amenorrhea.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation is concerning for Turner syndrome.

Turner syndrome is characterized by short stature and dysmorphic features, which may include a square chest, a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, a short fourth metacarpal bone, and more-subtle features such as a low posterior hairline; misshapen, low-set, small, or rotated ears; and a narrow palate with crowded teeth. Affected patients may also have congenital cardiac defects, ovarian insufficiency (streak ovaries), renal anomalies, vision problems, hearing loss, and learning difficulties. Most patients with Turner syndrome have normal intelligence.

Patients with Turner syndrome occasionally present as teenagers because they have failed to menstruate or develop secondary sexual characteristics. The diagnosis is established by a karyotype that shows complete or partial loss of the second sex chromosome (45,X) in all cells or in only some cells (mosaicism).

Key learning point: The most appropriate test for Turner syndrome is a karyotype.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents with concern about not yet having her period. According to her growth chart, she has had consistently low height (<1st percentile) and weight (5th percentile) since she was 3 years old. Her mother reached menarche at age 11.
On physical examination, the patient has a wide neck, broad chest, and high-arched palate. Breast development is consistent with sexual maturity rating (SMR; Tanner stage) 1 and pubic hair development with SMR 4.
Laboratory evaluation shows a karyotype of 45,X; a follicle-stimulating hormone level of 81 mIU/mL (reference range, 0.64–10.98); a luteinizing hormone level of 34 mIU/mL (0.04–10.80); an undetectable estradiol level; a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level; and normal levels of insulin-like growth factor 1 and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3.
Which one of the following screening evaluations is most important for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasound is used as part of the evaluation of primary amenorrhea but is not indicated in this patient, because the etiology of her amenorrhea has already been identified by the karyotype.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has Turner syndrome (45,X) with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and short stature. Classic physical findings in Turner syndrome include a wide neck, broad chest, and high-arched palate.

Compared with the general population, people with Turner syndrome are at increased risk for a range of conditions including congenital heart disease (bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, aortic dilatation), renal abnormalities (horseshoe kidney, renal aplasia, duplication of the renal pelvis, ureters, or vessels), thyroid disease, celiac disease, glucose intolerance, and skeletal abnormalities. Given this increased risk, screening tests are recommended at the time of Turner syndrome diagnosis, and some need to be repeated periodically. Recommended screening tests include echocardiography, renal ultrasound, bone mineral density testing (in adulthood), audiometric evaluation, ophthalmologic evaluation, thyroid and liver function testing, celiac disease screening, lipid assessment, and diabetes screening. Echocardiography should be repeated periodically because of the risk of aortic dilatation over time. Many initial screening tests would have already been done at the time of this patient’s diagnosis, and echocardiography is most important because of the ongoing risk of worsening dilatation of the aorta.

Key learning point: A patient with newly diagnosed Turner syndrome should undergo the following radiologic screening examinations: echocardiogram and renal ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation testing can be used to evaluate for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in patients with delayed puberty, but it is not helpful in the evaluation of patients with Turner syndrome, as these patients have primary gonadal dysgenesis and hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the short stature of Turner syndrome can be addressed with growth hormone, growth-hormone stimulation testing is not required, as girls with Turner syndrome do not typically have growth-hormone deficiency. In this case, the patient has normal levels of insulin-like growth factor 1 and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3, making such deficiency unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain can be used to evaluate the pituitary gland in patients with growth-hormone deficiency or hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, but it has no role in patients with Turner syndrome.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl is evaluated for short stature. She was born full term at 3200 grams. Her parents report that she has been small for her age since infancy but that the size discrepancy with her peers has become more obvious during the past year. She is a competitive athlete in field hockey and soccer, and her parents are concerned about the risk of injury because of her size. She has an excellent appetite with no gastrointestinal complaints and takes no medications. She excels in school.
She is currently 127 cm tall (5th percentile) and weighs 26 kg (5th–10th percentile). Her mother is 155 cm, and her father is 173 cm (midparental height, 157.5 cm); both parents report average pubertal timing.
On physical examination, breast development and pubic hair are consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 1. Her arm span is normal. A bone-age evaluation at 10 years, 0 months is consistent with chronologic age. The growth chart is available for review (figure).
What additional history or physical finding would be worrisome for an underlying growth disorder in this patient?

choices.text: History of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis as an infant
Absence of the sense of smell
History of fibrous dysplasia and café au lait macules

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Macrocephaly and learning differences are consistent with Sotos syndrome (cerebral gigantism), an overgrowth syndrome associated with excessive physical growth, typically in the first few years of life. Patients have characteristic facial features, learning differences, and delayed motor skills. This condition is not associated with short stature.

B) INCORRECT:

A history of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis as an infant could be a clue to autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type 1 (APS-1), which is associated with primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease), hypothyroidism, and type 1 diabetes. Pituitary hormone deficiencies, including growth-hormone deficiency, can occur in APS-1 but are not common. Although APS-1 could cause short stature, other manifestations would have also occurred by this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Anosmia, or absence of the sense of smell, is associated with idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in Kallmann syndrome. Although this syndrome can be associated with delayed onset of puberty, it is not typically associated with growth disorders. Given that this patient is only 10 years of age, it is not unusual or concerning that she has not had evidence of pubertal onset yet.

D) INCORRECT:

A history of fibrous dysplasia and café au lait macules is suggestive of McCune-Albright syndrome, which can be associated with gonadotropin-independent precocious puberty. Excess circulating estrogen in girls with this syndrome may cause rapid growth at an early age and, eventually, short stature related to advanced bone age. McCune-Albright syndrome can be associated with growth-hormone excess in some cases; short stature is not a typical presenting feature in this condition.

E) CORRECT:

Short stature is a common chief complaint and has a wide differential diagnosis that can be narrowed with a careful history, physical examination, and judicious use of imaging and laboratory analysis. In this case, the patient most likely has familial short stature, a normal pattern of growth characterized by normal growth velocity, growth within the child’s genetic potential (as determined by midparental height), and a bone age consistent with chronologic age.

Familial short stature does not require subspecialty referral or further investigation; however, clinicians should be alert for clues that could suggest an underlying growth disorder.

Bicuspid aortic valve is the most common cardiovascular anomaly in people with Turner syndrome. This syndrome may manifest in childhood with short stature or in adolescence with delayed puberty and primary or secondary amenorrhea. Although classic physical features are often noted on examination (e.g., widely spaced nipples, a short and webbed neck, cubitus valgus), subtle features may go undetected, thus contributing to a late diagnosis. Bicuspid aortic valve is more common in boys than girls, so its presence in a girl, especially one with slow growth, should be investigated thoroughly.

Key learning point: Children with short stature who are found to have bicuspid aortic valve should be evaluated for Turner syndrome.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman reports amenorrhea and absent sexual development. She has never had a menstrual period, breast development, or growth of pubic hair. She was born at term with no complications and reports doing well in school. Her mother reached menarche at age 13 (and has had regular menstrual cycles since then), and her 14-year-old sister started menstruating recently. The patient’s current height is 140 cm (below the third percentile), her weight is 45 kg (fifth percentile), and her body mass index is 23 kg/m2. She has no axillary or pubic hair, and her breast development is consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 1. She has atrophic vaginal mucosa; the cervix is present. Which of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Funduscopy is not likely to be diagnostic in a patient when the findings are consistent with Turner syndrome. A pituitary mass can lead to papilledema detectable by funduscopy, but a pituitary mass sufficient to cause papilledema and growth failure would likely also be associated with several endocrine deficiencies and visual disturbance.

B) INCORRECT:

Blood estradiol level results are likely to be abnormal in low-estrogen states, but abnormal findings on this test are not specific to Turner syndrome or to other causes of primary amenorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Progestin-withdrawal test results are likely to be abnormal in low-estrogen states, but abnormal findings on this test are not specific to Turner syndrome or to other causes of primary amenorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the FGFR1 gene lead to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, but not short stature.

E) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome is characterized by short stature and dysmorphic features, including a square chest, a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and a short fourth metacarpal bone. The characteristic features can be subtle but can also include a low posterior hairline, misshapen or rotated ears, and a narrow palate with crowded teeth. Affected patients may also have abnormalities in organogenesis, including coarctation, aortic dissection, and ovarian insufficiency (streak ovaries). Most patients with Turner syndrome have normal intelligence. Patients with Turner syndrome occasionally present as teenagers because they have failed to menstruate or develop secondary sexual characteristics. The diagnosis is established by a karyotype that shows only one sex chromosome (45, X) in all cells or in only some cells (mosaicism).

Key learning point: The most appropriate test for Turner syndrome is a karyotype.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the office because his parents are concerned about his persistently poor performance at school. On questioning, he reports that he is being bullied by his classmates for his high-pitched voice, thin build, and poor grades. He is at the 94th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows bilateral gynecomastia, sparse pubic hair, and long limbs compared with the trunk. Genital examination shows small, firm testes. Serum studies show increased levels of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone and a slightly decreased serum testosterone. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rather than an increased risk of developing prostate cancer, patients with Klinefelter syndrome have been found to have a significantly decreased incidence of and mortality from prostate cancer.

B) CORRECT:

Testicular hypoplasia in Klinefelter syndrome leads to decreased testosterone levels, which causes a loss of negative feedback on gonadotropins (e.g., LH, FSH). Elevated levels of FSH stimulate aromatase synthesis, which then stimulates the conversion of testosterone to estradiol. This leads to increased estrogen levels, one of the strongest predisposing factors of breast cancer. Compared with the general population, patients with Klinefelter syndrome have been found to have a 15- to 20-fold increased risk of developing breast cancer. Klinefelter syndrome also increases the risk of testicular and extragonadal germ cell tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

Inferior lens dislocation can be seen in patients with homocystinuria. In addition to ectopia lentis, patients with homocystinuria commonly present with tall stature and marfanoid habitus. Although this patient is at the 94th percentile for height, his laboratory findings of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and other physical examination findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1 increases the risk of developing neurofibromas and optic gliomas. Other characteristic features of NF type 1 include café-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules, tall stature, and mild-to-moderate cognitive delay. Although this patient's tall stature and poor school performance may support this diagnosis, he has no other features suggestive of NF type 1. Instead, his laboratory and other physical examination findings are consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which does not increase the risk of optic gliomas.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute myeloid and lymphocytic leukemias are commonly associated with Down syndrome (DS). Although this patient's poor school performance may suggest an underlying mild cognitive delay, he lacks typical features of DS, such as short stature, upward-slanting palpebral fissures, a single transverse palmar crease, and extensive intellectual disability. Finally, the patient's other symptoms (such as delayed puberty, gynecomastia) and laboratory results are inconsistent with DS.
questions.hint: This patient's physical appearance, impulsivity, poor performance at school (a potential sign of cognitive delay), and laboratory results indicating hypergonadotropic hypogonadism are strongly suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for a well-child visit. He attends a junior high school and is having difficulties keeping up with his classmates in many classes. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a high-frequency midsystolic click that is best heard at the left fifth intercostal space. The patient has long extremities along with excess breast tissue bilaterally. He has no axillary hair. Genital examination shows reduced scrotal size and a normal-sized penis. Which of the following tests is the most likely to diagnose the patient's underlying disorder?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient with tall stature, long extremities, and a mitral valve prolapse click, homocystinuria or Marfan syndrome might be suspected. Homocystinuria can also result in features of cognitive delay (e.g., poor scholastic performance). Both homocystinuria and Marfan syndrome can result in ectopia lentis, which is diagnosed by slit-lamp examination. However, gynecomastia, testicular hypoplasia, and decreased axillary hair are not features associated with these syndromes. Instead, other skeletal abnormalities such as arachnodactyly, chest wall deformities, hindfoot valgus, scoliosis and/or kyphosis would be seen.

B) INCORRECT:

In an adolescent with tall stature, a mitral valve prolapse click, and features suggestive of cognitive delay (e.g., poor scholastic performance), homocystinuria might be suspected. In this case, diagnostics should include urinalysis testing for increased urine homocysteine levels. However, gynecomastia, testicular hypoplasia, and decreased axillary hair are not features associated with this syndrome. Instead, other skeletal abnormalities such as arachnodactyly, chest wall deformities, hindfoot valgus, scoliosis, and/or kyphosis would be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the wrist in this patient with Klinefelter syndrome would most likely show a bone age that is equal to or less than the chronological age. However, since a number of causes of tall stature are associated with normal bone age (e.g., familial tall stature, obesity, Marfan syndrome, pituitary gigantism) or delayed bone age (e.g., estrogen insensitivity syndrome), this is a nonspecific finding in a patient with tall stature. A more specific test is required to diagnose Klinefelter syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Karyotyping is used to identify the sex chromosome trisomy associated with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY). The extra X chromosome (Barr body) interferes with testicular function, leading to impaired testosterone production. Treatment consists of lifelong testosterone substitution.

E) INCORRECT:

In a male adolescent with tall stature and a mitral valve prolapse click, Marfan syndrome or fragile X syndrome might be suspected. In this case, a PCR with Southern blot can be used to identify mutations in specific genes. However, neither of these conditions are typically associated with gynecomastia, testicular hypoplasia, or decreased axillary hair. Instead, Marfan syndrome would present with other skeletal findings such as arachnodactyly, chest wall deformities, hindfoot valgus, scoliosis, and/or kyphosis. Patients with fragile X syndrome would present with a long face, large ears, and large testicles (macroorchidism) at the time of puberty.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a eunuchoid growth pattern (tall, slim stature with long extremities), gynecomastia, reduced body hair, testicular hypoplasia, a mitral valve prolapse click, and poor scholastic performance (which might suggest cognitive delay). These features are consistent with the diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother because she has not yet begun menstruating. She has no significant medical history and feels well otherwise. Physical examination shows normally developed female external genitalia, sparse pubic and axillary hair, and normal breast development (Tanner stage 4). Pelvic ultrasound reveals absence of a uterus and only rudimentary internal structures, and clinical exam reveals a short blind vaginal pouch (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Testosterone
11 nmol/L
0.7 - 2.8 nmol/L


Follicle-stimulating hormone
20 IU/L
1.0 - 1.6 IU/L


Luteinizing hormone
25 U/L
3 - 15 U/L



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome results from a mutation in the androgen receptor gene, leading to androgen resistance in individuals with a 46,XY karyotype. Despite normal testicular testosterone production, tissues cannot respond to androgens, causing sparse pubic and axillary hair. Estrogen, derived from peripheral conversion of testosterone, supports normal breast development. Anti-Müllerian hormone from the testes causes regression of Müllerian structures, explaining the absence of a uterus and presence of a short blind vaginal pouch. Elevated testosterone, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone levels reflect the body's attempt to overcome androgen resistance.

Key learning point: Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, normal breast development, elevated testosterone levels, and lack of response to androgens, leading to sparse or absent pubic and axillary hair.

B) INCORRECT:

5-alpha reductase deficiency involves impaired conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, affecting male genitalia development. Patients may have undervirilized genitalia but typically lack pronounced breast development. The patient's well-developed breasts and sparse hair indicate effective estrogen production and compromised androgen activity, inconsistent with this deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Müllerian agenesis presents with absent uterus and a short vaginal pouch, but ovarian function remains intact, leading to normal testosterone levels and androgen-dependent hair distribution. The elevated testosterone and sparse hair in this patient suggest androgen insensitivity, not Müllerian agenesis. Additionally, gonadotropin levels are typically normal in Müllerian agenesis, unlike the elevated levels seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) usually occurs in individuals with a 46,XX karyotype, presenting with ovaries and a normal uterus. The absence of a uterus and rudimentary structures in this patient contradicts CAH. Additionally, CAH often presents with virilized genitalia and adrenal insufficiency, neither of which are observed here. The hormonal profile also does not align with CAH.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl with delayed puberty, short stature, and wide-spaced nipples presents with leg cramps and recurrent headaches. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects are not characteristically associated with Turner syndrome, which typically involves left-sided cardiac anomalies like coarctation of the aorta. The patient's symptoms of headaches and leg cramps are more indicative of vascular issues related to aortic anomalies rather than an interatrial shunt.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy involves asymmetric septal hypertrophy and is not linked to Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is associated with coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve. The patient's symptoms align with hemodynamic disturbances from aortic coarctation, not hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot, a conotruncal defect, presents with cyanosis and 'tet spells' in early childhood, which are absent here. Turner syndrome is more commonly associated with left-sided anomalies like coarctation of the aorta, leading to differential blood pressure and leg cramps, not the defects seen in Tetralogy of Fallot.

D) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome, characterized by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, is associated with congenital cardiovascular anomalies, notably coarctation of the aorta. This condition involves narrowing of the aorta, typically distal to the left subclavian artery, creating a pressure gradient between the upper and lower extremities. Clinically, this manifests as upper body hypertension, causing headaches, and reduced lower extremity perfusion, leading to leg cramps. The patient's short stature, delayed puberty, and wide-spaced nipples are consistent with Turner syndrome, supporting the likelihood of coarctation of the aorta.

Key learning point: Coarctation of the aorta is commonly associated with Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder affecting females.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to absence of menstrual cycles and lack of breast development. She has short stature and has had no significant growth spurts. Examination reveals a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, a webbed neck, and a low posterior hairline. She exhibits normal cognitive function. Blood pressure is higher in her upper extremities than in her lower extremities.
Which of the following chromosomal patterns is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Triple X syndrome (47, XXX) typically presents with normal pubertal development and tall stature. It lacks the physical findings of Turner syndrome, such as a webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Cardiovascular anomalies like coarctation of the aorta, indicated by blood pressure discrepancies, are not associated with triple X syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

A 46, XY karyotype is seen in genetic males and conditions like complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS). CAIS presents with well-developed breasts and taller stature, lacking the Turner syndrome features such as short stature, webbed neck, and cardiovascular anomalies like coarctation of the aorta.

C) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45, X karyotype, resulting from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. Clinical features include short stature, primary amenorrhea, and lack of breast development due to gonadal dysgenesis. Distinct physical findings such as a webbed neck, low posterior hairline, and a broad chest with widely spaced nipples are common. Cardiovascular anomalies, such as coarctation of the aorta, manifest as higher blood pressure in the upper extremities compared to the lower extremities. These features are consistent with the phenotype of Turner syndrome.

Key learning point: Turner syndrome is characterized by short stature, delayed puberty, webbed neck, and wide shield-like chest, and is caused by a chromosomal abnormality in females.

D) INCORRECT:

47, XXY is the karyotype for Klinefelter syndrome, which occurs in phenotypic males. It presents with tall stature, small testes, gynecomastia, and reduced facial and body hair. The clinical features of the patient, including primary amenorrhea, lack of breast development, and physical stigmata like a webbed neck, align with Turner syndrome, not Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea and minimal breast development. She is 143 cm tall and has a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and a low posterior hairline. Dorsalis pedis pulses are faint. She denies chest pain or dyspnea.

Blood pressure

154/88 mm Hg in the right arm, 118/76 mm Hg in the leg

Which of the following anomalies is most likely responsible for her elevated blood pressure?

choices.text: Bicuspid aortic valve with mild stenosis
Stenosis of the left subclavian artery
Narrowing of the thoracic aorta distal to the left subclavian artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unilateral renal artery narrowing can cause renovascular hypertension but does not typically result in the blood pressure discrepancy between the arms and legs. The clinical features and blood pressure pattern suggest an aortic arch abnormality, not a renal vascular issue.

B) INCORRECT:

Bicuspid aortic valve, common in Turner syndrome, can lead to a systolic murmur and progressive calcification. However, it does not cause the significant blood pressure differential between the upper and lower extremities seen here, which is more indicative of aortic coarctation.

C) INCORRECT:

Stenosis of the left subclavian artery would lead to lower blood pressure in the left arm compared to the right. The observed pattern of elevated right arm blood pressure and lower extremity hypotension is more consistent with coarctation of the aorta.

D) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome, characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, and primary amenorrhea, is associated with coarctation of the aorta. This narrowing typically occurs distal to the left subclavian artery, causing a pressure gradient between the upper and lower extremities. The elevated blood pressure in the arms compared to the legs results from this anatomical narrowing, which increases afterload on the left ventricle and poses long-term cardiovascular risks.

Key learning point: Turner syndrome is characterized by short stature, webbed neck, low hairline, primary amenorrhea, and can be associated with hypertension due to cardiovascular anomalies.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents for evaluation of delayed puberty. She is notably short for her age. Physical examination reveals a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, a high-arched palate, and cubitus valgus. She has had no menarche and denies any spontaneous breast development. Blood pressure is higher in the arms than in the legs.
Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Testicular tissue within the inguinal canal
Large ovarian cysts on pelvic ultrasound

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Testicular tissue in the inguinal canal is seen in conditions like complete androgen insensitivity syndrome in 46,XY individuals, who have female external genitalia and breast development. The patient's lack of breast development and features like short stature and coarctation of the aorta suggest Turner syndrome, not androgen insensitivity.

B) INCORRECT:

An absent uterus is characteristic of Müllerian agenesis, which presents with primary amenorrhea but normal secondary sexual development due to intact ovarian function. The lack of breast development and other features such as short stature and coarctation of the aorta in this patient suggest Turner syndrome, where the uterus is typically present, albeit hypoplastic.

C) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome, often due to a 45,X karyotype, manifests with gonadal dysgenesis, where the ovaries are replaced by fibrous tissue, known as 'streak ovaries'. This leads to primary amenorrhea, lack of breast development, and infertility. The syndrome also presents with short stature, a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, a high-arched palate, cubitus valgus, and cardiovascular anomalies like coarctation of the aorta. Pelvic ultrasound revealing streak ovaries confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating the underlying gonadal dysgenesis.

Key learning point: Turner syndrome is characterized by the karyotype 45X and presents with features such as short stature, wide-spaced nipples, and primary amenorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Large ovarian cysts are associated with conditions like polycystic ovarian syndrome, which involves preserved ovarian architecture and signs of androgen excess. In Turner syndrome, the ovaries are replaced by fibrotic streaks, not cystic structures, due to gonadal dysgenesis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with short stature and widely spaced nipples has thick, redundant skin folds at the back of her neck. She remains at Tanner stage I breast development. What best explains her neck findings?

choices.text: Skeletal dysplasia of the upper spine
Lymphatic outflow obstruction in embryonic development
Chronic infection of the cervical lymph nodes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skeletal dysplasia would present with bony abnormalities, not soft tissue findings like thick, redundant skin folds. The neck findings are due to lymphatic dysgenesis, as seen in Turner syndrome, rather than skeletal pathology.

B) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome is characterized by lymphatic outflow obstruction during embryonic development, leading to in utero lymphedema. This results in cystic hygroma, which manifests as a webbed neck with thick, redundant skin. Turner syndrome also presents with short stature, widely spaced nipples, and delayed pubertal development, aligning with the patient's presentation.

Key learning point: Redundant skin folds at the nape of the neck, or webbed neck, is a classic feature of Turner syndrome due to lymphedema.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic infection of cervical lymph nodes would present with tenderness, erythema, or systemic symptoms like fever, which are absent here. The thick, redundant skin folds suggest a developmental anomaly, consistent with Turner syndrome, rather than an inflammatory process.

D) INCORRECT:

Androgen overexposure in utero leads to virilization, not structural anomalies like a webbed neck. The patient's features, including short stature and delayed puberty, are consistent with Turner syndrome, not androgen excess.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for evaluation of delayed puberty. She is the shortest in her class and has not had menarche. Examination shows a webbed neck, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and low-set ears. She has normal intelligence. Laboratory evaluation reveals low estrogen.

Blood pressure
130/80 mm Hg

Which of the following is the most likely cause of her clinical features?

choices.text: Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5
Trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 causes Cri-du-chat syndrome, characterized by a high-pitched cry, developmental delays, and intellectual disability. The distinct facial features and microcephaly seen in Cri-du-chat differ from the webbed neck, broad chest, and low-set ears observed in this patient. Additionally, the normal intelligence and low estrogen levels in this patient are inconsistent with Cri-du-chat syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Robertsonian translocation involving chromosomes 14 and 21 is associated with Down syndrome, characterized by intellectual disability, epicanthal folds, and a flat facial profile. The patient's normal intelligence and features such as a webbed neck and broad chest are more indicative of Turner syndrome, which involves monosomy X rather than a translocation event.

C) INCORRECT:

Trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene causes Fragile X syndrome, which typically presents with intellectual disability and distinct facial features. Females may have learning disabilities or behavioral issues, but the somatic features in this patient, such as a webbed neck and broad chest, do not align with Fragile X syndrome. The normal intelligence and specific physical findings suggest a different genetic etiology.

D) CORRECT:

Turner syndrome results from the absence of all or part of one X chromosome, typically manifesting as a 45,X karyotype. This chromosomal anomaly leads to gonadal dysgenesis, resulting in streak ovaries and low estrogen levels, causing delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea. Physical features include short stature, webbed neck, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and low-set ears. Cardiovascular anomalies, such as coarctation of the aorta, are also associated with Turner syndrome, aligning with the observed blood pressure findings.

Key learning point: Turner's syndrome is characterized by short stature, webbed neck, delayed puberty, high-arched palate, and low-set posterior hairline, and is due to a missing or partially missing X chromosome in females.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother because she has not begun menstruating. Her height is below the 5th percentile. Her mother notes that both she and the patient’s father are of average height and had normal pubertal timelines. Examination shows a broad chest, widely spaced nipples, a webbed neck, a wide carrying angle at the elbows, and no sign of breast development.
Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the pituitary

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Karyotype analysis is essential for confirming Turner syndrome, which is characterized by the 45,X karyotype or mosaic variants. The patient's features, including short stature, webbed neck, broad chest, and primary amenorrhea, suggest a chromosomal disorder. Karyotyping identifies the missing or abnormal sex chromosome, confirming the diagnosis and guiding management, including evaluation for associated conditions like cardiac or renal anomalies and planning hormone replacement therapy.

Key learning point: Chromosomal analysis is the most definitive diagnostic test for Turner syndrome, which presents with features such as short stature, webbed neck, and delayed puberty.

B) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasound assesses reproductive anatomy but cannot identify chromosomal anomalies. While it may show a hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries, these findings are not specific to Turner syndrome and do not confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pituitary is used for central causes of delayed puberty. The patient's features suggest a chromosomal disorder, not a central defect, making pituitary MRI irrelevant for confirming Turner syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) measurement can indicate hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, suggesting ovarian failure. However, elevated FSH is not specific to Turner syndrome and does not confirm the chromosomal abnormality suggested by the patient's physical features.

questions.text: You are caring for a term female newborn, birth weight 3400 g, delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is swelling of both upper and lower extremities, low-set ears, a low posterior hairline, a broad chest, and skin folds extending from the sides of the neck to the shoulders. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur and a systolic click at the apex. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of this newborn's swelling?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired left ventricular (LV) function can cause increased hydrostatic pressure and subsequent edema via two main mechanisms: increased renal sodium retention (as a response to decreased renal perfusion) and increased venous pressure. This newborn has a systolic murmur that suggests a bicuspid aortic valve, which could progress to aortic stenosis or insufficiency and cause left-sided heart failure (LHF). However, LHF typically manifests with signs of pulmonary (e.g., tachypnea, basilar rales) rather than peripheral edema. Furthermore, this patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

B) CORRECT:

Dysfunction of the lymphatic system is characteristic of Turner syndrome and typically leads to congenital lymphedema of the hands and feet starting in the neonatal period. The precise cause of lymphatic dysfunction in Turner syndrome is unknown. This patient also has other typical features of the condition, such as a female phenotype, shield chest, a short, webbed neck, low-set ears, and signs of a bicuspid aortic valve (grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur and systolic click at the apex).

Key learning point: Congenital lymphedema of the hands and feet in Turner syndrome results from dysfunctional lymphatic system development.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal retention of sodium can be a compensatory response to decreased kidney perfusion (resulting from, e.g., heart failure or chronic kidney disease) and can cause edema of the extremities. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which is associated with both cardiovascular abnormalities (e.g., bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension) and kidney disease (e.g., horseshoe kidneys) that can progress to severe cardiac or renal insufficiency with consequent renal hypoperfusion. However, this child has no other signs and symptoms to suggest cardiac or renal insufficiency. In addition, edema of the hands and feet in neonates with Turner syndrome has a different underlying mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased capillary permeability (e.g., due to inflammation, burns, allergic reactions) can lead to extravasation of fluid into the tissue and subsequent edema. However, edema is usually localized to the area of tissue injury or generalized in systemic reactions (e.g., sepsis, anaphylaxis). Peripheral edema of the hands and feet bilaterally would be untypical. Furthermore, this patient shows no symptoms of localized tissue damage such as erythema, and her normal vital signs make a systemic reaction unlikely. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive urinary protein loss (e.g., in nephrotic syndrome) can lead to decreased serum colloid osmotic pressure and subsequent edema. However, nephrotic syndrome is rare in newborns and the edema in nephrotic syndrome typically begins in the periorbital region rather than the extremities. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.
questions.hint: This newborn's systolic ejection murmur and systolic click at the apex suggest a functional bicuspid aortic valve.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to your clinic because she has not yet attained menarche. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 168 cm tall and weighs 63 kg; BMI is 22. On examination, she has normal breast development and scant axillary hair. Abdominal examination reveals a firm, nontender left inguinal mass. Pelvic examination shows a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography does not show a uterus or ovaries. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mullerian duct agenesis results in primary amenorrhea, an absent uterus on ultrasound, and a blind vaginal pouch due to vaginal atresia. However, the ovaries would be present. Axillary hair growth would also be normal since primary amenorrhea in patients with Mullerian duct agenesis is the result of an anatomical defect and not a hormonal one.

B) INCORRECT:

A defect in the SRY gene on chromosome Y results in Swyer syndrome, which manifests with primary amenorrhea and absent or atretic ovaries on ultrasound. However, normal development of axillary hair would occur (due to adrenal androgens), and a uterus would be present. Also, breast development would be impaired, and palpable testes would not be present.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) are karyotypically male (XY). The Y chromosome results in the formation of the testes (instead of the ovaries) from the undifferentiated fetal gonad. The uterus does not develop because the anti-Mullerian hormone secreted by the testes causes Mullerian duct atresia.
